Rafael “Rafe” Calder was raised in a rough coastal city by a mother who swore their bloodline carried an old sea-god’s debt, and he’s spent his life trying to outrun the consequences. He works nights as a harbor security contractor, the kind people call when the police won’t, and the kind who knows too much about what washes in with the tide. Guarded, fiercely loyal, and quietly tender beneath the grit, he keeps everyone at arm’s length until they prove they can survive his world. His driving goal is to pay off the “debt” by stopping a string of ritual drownings tied to his family name—without letting himself need the one person who makes him feel human again.

messages.content:
Berth 12 smells like diesel and fish rot. It’s after midnight, and fog presses against the docklights until they buzz. Rafe Calder tastes salt at the back of his tongue, the way he did when his mother whispered about a debt that ends in water.

He tells himself he works nights because the pay stays better and the questions stay fewer. He checks padlocks for a bait shop that can’t afford another break-in. He writes times in a small notebook because cameras “fail” when the Harbor Authority wants them to. His phone keeps vibrating in his jacket, and he keeps ignoring it.

A body bumps the pilings and rolls half into view. A Harbor Authority accident tag hangs from the toe, stapled clean through skin. The ink still shines. Rafe steps closer and reads the time of death. It lists tomorrow.

A voice behind him says, “Don’t touch it.” A woman stands under the light with a cheap raincoat and a bruised look around her eyes. She holds a first aid kit like she brought it out of habit, not hope. Her hands shake, but she still looks at the man’s face like he mattered. Rafe doesn’t ask why she’s here. He knows why people come to the water at night.

She crouches anyway and pulls the tag loose with careful fingers. “He has a kid,” she says. Her throat works. “I saw him on the picket line.”

Rafe feels anger come up clean and hot. Not at her. At the neat staple. At the time stamp. At the way the harbor keeps taking and calling it paperwork.

Footsteps scrape on the planks. A flashlight beam cuts the fog. Someone calls out, “Authority sweep. Show your hands.”
I lift my hands slow, stepping half in front of her like it’s casual. “Easy—Calder. I’m contracted security on this stretch. Who’s running the sweep tonight?”
messages.player_reasoning: Harbor Authority loves to pin things on whoever’s closest; I need to keep her out of the line of fire and see who’s sweeping without giving up ground.

messages.content:
The flashlight beam steadies when you say “Calder.” The boots stop a few planks short, like the name is a line they don’t want to cross without orders.

“Yeah,” a man answers from the fog, voice tight. “Contractor. I know who you are.” He steps into the cone of light: Harbor Authority inspector’s jacket over street clothes, badge on a lanyard instead of pinned—**Inspector Dain Rook**. His knuckles are white around the flashlight. Behind him, two Authority uniforms fan out, one angling their light toward the water, the other toward the stacked containers to the east.

Rook doesn’t answer your question directly. “Commissioner Harrow’s running it,” he says, and the way he says it makes it sound like he’s repeating someone else’s line. His eyes flick past you—trying to see the woman you’re half-blocking—then down to the body. “This is an accident scene. You didn’t see it. You didn’t log it.”

The woman behind you inhales sharply; you feel it more than hear it. She keeps her hands close to her raincoat pockets, like she’s hiding the torn-off tag or just her shaking.

To the west, down the berth, another set of lights sweeps across doors and padlocks—someone else is already checking businesses, tugging on chains, writing something down. Over the water, the buoy bell strikes off-beat again, late by a heartbeat.

Rook takes one step closer, lowering his voice. “I can make your name disappear from tonight’s sweep. I need your security logs. Last three nights. Every camera you’ve got access to.” His gaze hardens. “And you’re going to tell your… friend… to go home before she becomes a problem Harrow solves.”

One of the uniforms calls, “Inspector—Union pickets two piers over. They’re moving this way.”

Rook’s jaw ticks. “Clock’s bad tonight,” he mutters, almost to himself, then looks back at you. “So. Who’s running the sweep? Harrow. And she’s hungry.”

**Status updates:** Authority sweep converging; Union patrol nearby; Rook demands three nights’ logs.

I keep my hands up but angle my body to block their line of sight to her. “You don’t get three nights of my logs on a whisper and a threat—tell Harrow to file a request like everyone else.” I glance back at the woman, low and firm: “Walk. Now. Don’t run—just go,” then I look back to Rook. “You want help? Start by telling me why the toe tag says tomorrow.”
messages.player_reasoning: Rook’s scared of Harrow and trying to squeeze me; I need to protect the woman and keep leverage without handing over everything.

messages.content:
Your body angle works: the uniforms’ lights keep on you and the corpse, not her. The woman takes the cue. She slips sideways along the shadowed edge of a container stack, head down, walking—fast but not running—until the fog swallows her raincoat.

Rook notices a beat too late. His flashlight twitches toward where she went, then snaps back to you, jaw clenched. “Dammit, Calder.” He doesn’t order pursuit—either he can’t spare the manpower, or he doesn’t want a report that says a civilian witness got chased.

The dock under your boots is slick with brine; when the buoy bell hits again it’s still off, like the harbor’s metronome is wrong on purpose. Down-berth, the other sweep team’s lights flare against corrugated doors—padlocks rattling, someone jotting serial numbers.

Rook leans in close enough you catch stale coffee on his breath. “Because it was printed before he died,” he says, voice low. “Tags, forms, timestamps—pre-staged. Harrow calls it ‘administrative efficiency.’” His eyes flick to the toe tag you’re staring at. “And if you’re thinking that’s impossible—welcome to my week.”

One of the uniformed officers, a woman with a clipped ponytail, moves to the body and starts photographing the tag and the face, quick and practiced. The other keeps watch toward the west, where distant voices and the clack of boots on planks are getting louder—Union patrol closing.

Rook’s hand shakes when he points his flashlight at your chest, not quite a threat, more like he needs something to hold onto. “I’m not here to burn you. I’m here because if this goes into the system the wrong way, Harrow buries it and the Union riots over it.” His voice drops further. “You want the real answer? Someone above me is running the paperwork ahead of the water. I don’t know how. I just know Harrow’s orders are to seize every private camera angle before sunrise.”

He glances toward the fog where the woman vanished. “If she talks to Brinehand first, they’ll decide you’re the saboteur. If she talks to Tideglass… she won’t talk again.”

**Status updates:** Witness extracted into fog. Union patrol nearing Berth 12. Rook admits pre-staged tags.

I step in closer so only Rook hears me. “You want cameras? You get one angle, one hour—right now—on my device, and you don’t copy it. You try to seize my logs, I’ll make sure the Union hears you’re scrubbing bodies with tomorrow’s paperwork.”

I flick my eyes toward the approaching boots. “When they hit this pier, you tell your people to stand down and let me talk them off. While they’re yelling, you and I walk—quiet—toward the container stack. You’re going to tell me what Brinehand and Tideglass are, and you’re going to tell me where Harrow keeps the printer that can see the future.”
messages.player_reasoning: Rook’s scared and talking too much—means Harrow’s pressure is real. Union’s coming, so I need to control the narrative fast, keep the witness alive, and not hand over my logs outright. I’ll give Rook a limited slice to buy time and use the Union arrival as cover to move.

messages.content:
Rook’s eyes harden at the blackmail, then flick past you to the fog like he’s weighing which fire burns him slower. He gives a tight nod—once. “One angle. One hour. On your device,” he breathes. “No copy.” It’s not trust; it’s triage.

He turns half toward his uniforms and raises his voice just enough to carry. “Hold position. Nobody touches private equipment without my say.” The ponytailed officer pauses mid-photo, annoyed but obedient. The other officer shifts his stance, light trained west where the boots are getting loud.

The air tastes like pennies and salt. To the east, the container stack looms like a dark wall, the fog snagging on its corners and sliding down in sheets. The buoy bell hits again—late.

Union voices swell: rough laughter, a shouted name, the scrape of hook-knives on belt rivets. Rook leans close as you start drifting—casual, unhurried—toward the containers.

“Brinehand’s the union’s teeth,” he murmurs. “They keep the docks ‘safe’ for a price. They also… pay the water. Names go missing when the tide’s wrong.” His throat works. “Tideglass is worse. Charity front. Ledgers, bloodlines, tide charts. They don’t muscle you—they *schedule* you.”

A shout breaks closer: “Authority! Hands off our men!” One of the uniforms starts to answer, but Rook snaps, “Stand down,” like he’s swallowing a lifetime of training.

You and Rook reach the container stack’s shadow. The temperature drops a degree. His voice goes even lower. “Printer that sees the future?” He shakes his head. “Harrow doesn’t keep it in her office. Paperwork comes out of the Harbor Records annex—old building behind **Ing Boots**. Basement. Restricted after the flood. That’s where the tags get ‘processed’ before they ever hit a toe.”

As you edge along the containers, a faint gritty crunch underfoot—salt embedded where it shouldn’t be—clings to the sole of your boot like it’s trying to *remember* you crossed here.

**Status updates:** Rook accepts one-hour view. Union patrol at pier mouth. Harrow link: Records annex basement.

I peel away from the container shadow and head toward the Union voices with my palms open. “Hey—easy. Nobody’s putting hands on anybody. There’s a body in the water and Authority’s already twitchy; you want answers, not an excuse to crack skulls.”  

Then I glance back at Rook. “You keep your people leashed like you promised. After I cool them off, you and I watch that one hour—right here—then I’m going to the annex behind Ing Boots. If you’re lying, Rook, I’ll say your name out loud where it carries.”
messages.player_reasoning: Rook finally gave me something real—location, names, motive. I need to keep the Union from turning this into a brawl, then lock down that “one hour” bargain and get moving toward the Records annex before Harrow scrubs everything.

messages.content: I step into the docklight with my palms open toward the Union voices. “Oi—hold up. Nobody swings tonight. There’s a body in the water and if you give Authority a riot, they’ll bury the facts with it.” I hook a thumb back at Rook without looking away from the approaching boots. “Inspector promised his people stay leashed; you want answers, you let me talk—then we all walk away with our teeth still in our mouths.”
messages.player_reasoning: The Union’s about to collide with Authority—if this turns into a brawl, the body and the “tomorrow” tag vanish into chaos. I need to de-escalate fast, keep Rook accountable, and buy myself room to move on the annex lead.

messages.content:
You step into the stuttering pool of docklight, palms up. The fog makes your hands look farther away than they are—like you’re offering them to the pier.

The approaching boots slow. Two Brinehand “Night Hands” in oilskins resolve out of the haze by the bait-warehouse shutters, exactly where the darkness is thickest. One has a short gaff hook tucked along his forearm like it’s just another tool; the other keeps his hand near his coat where something metal prints against the fabric. They don’t rush you—your tone and the mention of “riot” lands—but they also don’t stop moving. They angle to bracket you, eyes flicking past your shoulders to Rook and the Authority lights.

“Inspector promised,” the gaff-hand repeats, voice rough with dock smoke. “Inspectors promise a lot.” He tips his chin toward the body. “That one ours. Picket. And we heard he was talking to a *Calder*.”

Behind you, Rook holds his line. He barks, “No contact. No seizures. Stand down,” and for once his uniforms actually do—flashlights dip, batons stay holstered. The ponytailed officer mutters something under her breath but steps back from the corpse.

The second Night Hand sniffs, like he can smell the ink. “Tag’s fresh,” he says. “Accident label already on him—means Authority’s doing favors for somebody. You telling me who’s paying the water now, Calder? Or you want us asking your friends on every pier?”

A gust pushes the fog sideways; for a heartbeat you can see the corrugated bait-warehouse slit they’d been watching from, rust scraped clean to a bright line. The buoy bell rings again—still off, still wrong—and the Union men glance at the sound like they’ve been trained to hear it as a warning.

Time pressure tightens: if Brinehand decides you’re stalling, they’ll take you or take Rook; if Authority panics, they’ll “secure” the scene and disappear the body. In the middle, the corpse’s toe tag flutters, ink tacky enough to catch dock grit.

**Status updates:** Brinehand Night Hands engaged. Authority holding (for now). Scene on a knife-edge.

I keep my hands up and my voice low, steady. “Nobody’s paying the water—someone’s paying *paper* to make it look clean. That tag’s dated tomorrow; if you’ve got men dying on schedule, you’re already on the menu.”

I nod toward the body, then angle my chin toward the Authority lights without challenging them. “Rook’s got his people leashed and I’m keeping it that way. You want answers, give me one hour to show you what my camera saw—then you send one pair of eyes with me to Harbor Records behind Ing Boots. Quiet. No mob, no batons, no excuses.”

I look the gaff-hand straight on. “You said he was talking to a Calder—was it me, or my family name? And what did he say before he went in the drink?”
messages.player_reasoning: Brinehand’s probing for leverage; I need to keep them from grabbing Rook or escalating, and use the “tomorrow” tag as common ground to pivot them toward the annex lead without naming the woman.

messages.content:
The word **“tomorrow”** hits them like a thrown nail.

The gaff-hand’s posture changes first—shoulders easing a fraction, hook-hand lowering from “ready” to “present.” The other Night Hand stops trying to slide around your flank and instead plants his boots square, eyes narrowing as he looks at the toe tag like it might bite. You don’t win trust, but you win a pause; the brine in the air feels less like a brawl and more like a negotiation.

“Paper don’t float,” the gaff-hand mutters, then glances past you toward the Authority lights. “But it does *sink* a man.”

Behind you, Rook keeps his people still. One uniform’s radio crackles; Rook covers the mic with his palm and hisses something you can’t catch. Out on the fog line, a low engine note idles—steady, patient—like a skiff holding position without wanting to be seen.

The gaff-hand answers your question without blinking. “Family name,” he says. “Not you personally. He said Tideglass has a ledger that don’t just list donations. Lists **debts**. Lists **blood**.” He jerks his chin at the corpse. “He said Pier Nine’s memorial ain’t a memorial. It’s a window. He said your name shows up when the tide chart hits a certain minute.”

The second Night Hand finally speaks, voice flat. “Last thing he said to me was: ‘If I go under, check the inside of my boot.’ Then he laughed—like he already knew what time he was supposed to die.”

The gaff-hand looks you over again, weighing the hour you asked for. “One pair of eyes, quiet,” he repeats. “Fine. But if your footage is smoke, Calder, we don’t come back asking.”

He gestures with two fingers; the second Night Hand steps toward the body—not to touch it, but to stare at the boots, intent and hungry for that detail.

**Status updates:** Brinehand backs off (conditional).  
**Status updates:** Pier Nine + Tideglass ledger confirmed.  
**Status updates:** “Inside his boot” lead surfaced.

I hold up a finger to the Night Hand edging toward the boots. “Not your hands. Not theirs either. We do it clean—Rook, you pull the boot, I watch, your camera girl documents, and your people don’t start bagging anything until I say.”  

I cut my eyes to the fog line, listening to that idling engine. “And one of you—quiet—tell me who’s sitting out there in a skiff pretending they’re not.”  

Then back to the gaff-hand, steady. “You get your one pair of eyes on me for the annex, but first we see what he hid in his boot. If my family’s in a Tideglass ledger, I want to know what kind of ink they used.”
messages.player_reasoning: The “inside his boot” lead is immediate and could disappear if Authority seals the body; I need to keep Brinehand calm, keep Rook honest, and clock that skiff in the fog as a potential Tideglass watcher. I’ll propose a controlled check of the boot with everyone watching, then pivot to the one-hour footage deal.

messages.content:
I keep my palms visible and point a finger at the body’s boots. “Nobody touches him bare-handed—Union or Authority. Rook, you do the pull with gloves while your camera officer documents, and nobody bags a damn thing until I’ve seen it.”  

I tilt my head toward the fog line, listening to that idling motor. “And one of you Night Hands—quiet—tell me who’s out there in the skiff pretending they aren’t.”
messages.player_reasoning: The screen’s blank—no new info—so I’ll press the immediate leverage points: control the evidence handling, confirm the skiff threat, and get the boot checked without letting either side snatch it.

messages.content:
Rook hesitates at your “until I say,” jaw working—then he makes a tight, angry decision and turns it into procedure. “Gloves. Evidence line. Now,” he snaps, like it was his idea. The ponytailed officer—camera girl—pulls a small body-cam unit from her vest and taps it on; the red record light winks through the fog.

You’re still at Berth 12, right at the edge where docklight dies into black water. The corpse lies half in a puddle of brine-slick runoff; the toe tag flutters against the boot leather, ink shining wet.

Rook kneels, latex gloves snapping on. He grips the dead man’s ankle and works the boot carefully, twisting to break suction. Leather squeals. The Night Hand you checked stops short, teeth grinding, but he listens.

The boot finally slides free with a soft, ugly *schlop*. Rook tips it upside down over a clean evidence bag the camera officer holds open.

A rolled strip of waxed paper drops out—tight as a cigarette—followed by a small, flat brass token stamped with a buoy-bell symbol. The paper’s edge is stained with salt and something like old ink.

At your mention of the skiff, the second Night Hand answers without looking at you. “Not ours,” he murmurs. “That’s Tideglass. They sit off like that when they’re counting minutes.” He flicks his eyes toward the fog line. “Single outboard, muffled. One person. Raincoat.”

As if on cue, the idling motor note shifts—just a hair higher—then eases back, like whoever’s out there heard their name spoken and is deciding whether to drift closer or vanish.

Behind you, one Authority radio chirps again. Rook clamps it shut with his palm, but you catch a phrase: “…Night Compliance… van on—” then static.

**Status updates:** Boot contents recovered (paper + token)  
**Status updates:** Skiff ID: Tideglass watcher  
**Status updates:** Authority comms tightening up

I lean in close to the evidence bag. “Don’t unroll it in the open—wind’ll steal it. Camera on tight, then we read it with our bodies blocking.”  

I glance at Rook, voice like a blade. “You heard ‘Night Compliance van.’ If that shows, you stall them—jurisdictional pissing match, whatever you’re good at.”  

Then I nod at the Night Hands. “One of you keep eyes on that fog-line skiff and tell me if it moves. If Tideglass is counting minutes, I want to hear the number change.”
messages.player_reasoning: The token and note are the only real leverage before Authority locks this down; Tideglass watching means we’re on a clock, and “Night Compliance van” sounds like a cleanup crew. I need the note read/secured and eyes on that skiff without escalating into a fight.

messages.content:
Rook gives you a hard look—like he hates taking cues from a contractor—then nods once. “Fine. Tight read. No theatrics.”

The camera officer steps in close, shoulders hunched to make a human wall. You, Rook, and her form a tight wedge over the evidence bag; fog beads on your lashes, and the docklight behind you turns the bag’s plastic into a milky glare until she angles it to kill the reflection.

Rook pinches the waxed paper with gloved fingers and eases it open inside the bag. The paper crackles softly, the sound too loud in the hush.

Inside: a smear of blue-black ink, written fast but deliberate.

> **PIER NINE — LOW TIDE WINDOW**  
> **23:48** (bell count starts)  
> **CALDER MARK CONFIRMED**  
> **“RETURNED” FILED BEFORE WATER**  
> **BRING TOKEN TO ANNEX DOOR / NO LIGHTS**

Under that, a line of numbers—short, like a code—then a name that makes your tongue taste like pennies:

> **RAFE**

Rook’s eyes flick to you, then away, like he’s seen enough to know this isn’t just port paperwork anymore. “Night Compliance van’s Harrow’s people,” he mutters, low. “Not my unit. If they show, I can stall—five minutes, maybe ten—before they start asking why I’m standing over a body with Union this close.”

Off to your right, the gaff-hand Night Hand shifts his stance and raises a battered pair of dock binoculars. “I got the fog line,” he says. “If that skiff breathes, you’ll hear it.”

Out on the water, the idling motor note dips—then cuts for half a second—then returns, quieter. The skiff isn’t leaving. It’s adjusting position to keep you in view without giving you a clean bearing.

Somewhere deeper in the fog, tires hiss on wet asphalt—slow, heavy—coming toward Berth 12 like they already know where to stop.

**Status updates:** Note names Pier Nine 23:48  
**Status updates:** Tideglass wants annex token  
**Status updates:** Harrow van inbound (near)**

I swallow hard and keep my voice level. “Rook—bag the note as evidence and keep it. The token comes with me. If Harrow asks, you never saw it.”  

I turn to the gaff-hand. “You want answers? You’re my one pair of eyes. You’re coming with me—quiet—to this annex door. Tell your people to stand down and watch that skiff.”  

Then I lean toward the camera officer. “What’s that short number line—can you zoom and read it clean for me before the van rolls in?”
messages.player_reasoning: My name on that note means this is personal and timed; Harrow’s van will lock the scene down, so I need to move the token and the lead out of here fast while keeping Rook and the Union from colliding.

messages.content:
Rook’s nostrils flare, but he moves fast—like he’s decided speed is the only kind of control left. He seals the waxed note in the evidence bag, slaps a Harbor seal across it, and tucks it into his coat. “I never saw a token,” he says flatly, not looking at you when he says it. The lie lands clean.

You pocket the brass buoy-bell token; it’s colder than the air and leaves a faint metallic-salt smell on your fingers.

The gaff-hand Night Hand—broad shoulders, knuckles split old and new—hesitates when you tell him to come. Then he gives a short nod. “Name’s Jory,” he mutters. “I’m not your friend, Calder. But I want the truth more than I want Union stories.” He cups his hands and calls low to the other Night Hands without turning his head: “Stand down. Eyes on the fog line. No hero shit.” The others melt back toward the pilings, one keeping the binoculars trained on the skiff’s last whisper of engine noise.

The camera officer leans in, thumb working her device. “Hold,” she says, voice tight. She zooms into the bag, fights the glare, then angles her body to block the docklight. In the screen’s cold glow, the short number line resolves:

**09 — 12 — 03 — 48**  
…and beneath it, smaller: **“BELL / WRONG”**

Her eyes flick up to you. “Could be a time split. Or berth numbers. Or… a sequence.”

Down the access road behind the stacked containers, tires hiss again—closer now. A van’s headlights smear through the fog, low and wide, and you catch the silhouette of a roof bar without the courtesy of sirens.

Rook straightens, already putting on his “jurisdiction” face. “Go,” he murmurs at you, almost inaudible. “Before they pin you to this scene.”

**Status updates:** Token concealed on Rafe  
**Status updates:** Note sealed with Rook  
**Status updates:** Jory joins (quiet)  
**Status updates:** Night Compliance van arriving

I grip Jory’s sleeve and pull him into the shadow between containers. “Pier Nine, 23:48—low tide window. We move now, quiet.”  

As we go, I murmur, “09-12-03-48… could be berth markers; keep your ears for bell counts—if they ring wrong, we turn.”  

I shoot Rook a last look over my shoulder. “Ten minutes. Then you don’t know me.”
messages.player_reasoning: Harrow’s van means I’m about to get boxed in; I need to disappear with Jory and the token, and the number line feels like a time/berth cue pointing to Pier Nine at 23:48.

messages.content:
You yank Jory into the container-shadow and he moves with you, low and fast—no argument, just a grim set to his jaw. The Night Compliance van’s headlights sweep the berth behind you; you hear a door thunk and clipped voices, but the fog and steel stacks swallow you before anyone gets a clean look.

Between containers the air changes—hotter, sour with old citrus rot and diesel. Condensation drips off corrugated walls in slow ticks. Your footfalls go dull on gritty concrete, and the buoy bell out in the harbor keeps that *almost-right* rhythm, like a song you know with one note bent.

Behind you, Rook steps into the wash of the van’s lights and starts talking loud—official, annoyed. “This is an active recovery scene under my seal—identify your supervisor—” The reply is sharper, female, and close enough to carry: “Commissioner Harrow’s sweep. Hand over all footage and any evidence collected tonight.” Rook doesn’t yield, but you can hear the clock in how he talks: buying minutes with rules.

Jory leans in as you move. “Pier Nine’s a straight shot if we cut through the reefer lane and hop the service catwalk,” he murmurs. “But ‘Annex door’—that’s not on the public maps. Authority’s got an annex by the old pump house, west end of Pier Nine. Steel door. No signage. They use it when they don’t want a log.”

At the mention of the number line, he nods once. “09-12-03-48… Berth Twelve’s obvious. Nine could be Pier Nine. Three’s… the third ladderwell on the catwalk, maybe. Forty-eight—could be a locker, or a light pole ID.” He pauses, listening.

The buoy bell rings again—then a fraction early, like it’s skipping ahead. Jory’s eyes sharpen. “That’s what you meant by ‘wrong.’ Someone’s messing with the count. Tideglass does that—sets a rhythm so their people know they’re on-time.”

Far off to your right, out past the stacks, an outboard motor coughs once—fog-line skiff repositioning—and then goes quiet again.

**Status updates:** Slipped van line-of-sight  
**Status updates:** Rook stalling Harrow sweep  
**Status updates:** Jory IDs “annex” near Pier Nine pump house  
**Status updates:** Buoy bell count drifting

I keep moving, shoulders tight to the containers. “Third ladderwell, light pole forty-eight—sounds like a meet point. If you’re steering me wrong, Jory, I’ll know the second the bell skips again.”

I slow just long enough to listen, counting under my breath with the buoy—then gesture ahead. “Reefer lane, catwalk. You go first at the ladder, quiet and low.”

As we slip forward, I murmur, “That skiff cough was a check-in. If we see anyone near the pump house, we don’t confront—just mark faces and get to that steel door.”
messages.player_reasoning: The bell rhythm feels like a lure and a timer; I need to get to the annex fast but not walk into an ambush. I’ll use the numbers as navigation while keeping Jory close and testing his loyalties.

messages.content:
Jory goes first without protest, palms flat on the container seam, then slips into the reefer lane where the air turns sharply colder—fans humming inside stacked refrigerated boxes like a distant swarm. He finds the ladder welded to the catwalk support and tests it with a slow, controlled pull before putting weight on it. No rattle. He climbs low and tight, boots landing on rungs like he’s done it a thousand nights.

You pause beneath the ladder and count the buoy bell under your breath.

…one… two… three—

The next ring comes *half a beat early*. Not a drift this time; a deliberate skip.

Jory freezes on the catwalk above you, head cocked. “That’s a signal,” he whispers down. “Not tide. Not wind. Someone’s pulling the rhythm on purpose.”

When you climb up after him, the catwalk gives you a narrow view west toward Pier Nine: fog lit from below by sodium lamps, turning everything into silhouettes and smears. You catch **Light Pole 48** stenciled in flaking white on a post at the far end of the lane—exactly where the service catwalk angles toward the old pump house annex.

Below, in the fog at ground level, two figures move along the reefer row—slow, not working. Harbor-cut raincoats, hands in pockets. One stops under a camera dome and tilts their head like they’re listening to an earpiece. The other drags something wheeled for a second—then lifts it, carrying it to keep it quiet.

Jory’s voice is barely breath. “Those aren’t Union patrol. Union boys swagger. Those two are… measured.” He glances back at you. “If they’re there, they’re there for the door.”

Out on the waterline, the skiff coughs again—one quick choke, then silence—like a confirmation ping.

From behind, faint through the container maze, you hear Harrow’s sweep still chewing up Berth 12: a door slam, a raised voice, then Rook’s controlled bark answering back. He’s still buying time, but the noise is moving—slowly—your way.

Jory edges forward on the catwalk toward the third ladderwell, shoulders hunched to keep his silhouette small. “Third ladder’s ahead,” he murmurs. “If Pole 48 is the meet, they’ll be watching *under* it, not *at* it.”

**Status updates:** Buoy bell: deliberate skip  
**Status updates:** Two watchers near reefer row  
**Status updates:** Light Pole 48 sighted  
**Status updates:** Harrow sweep drifting closer

I grab Jory’s shoulder and pull him down into a crouch on the catwalk. “We don’t go down that ladder into them—stay high.”  

I watch the two raincoats for a beat, then whisper, “When the bell skips again, we move—fast—past Pole 48 and straight for that pump house door. No hero moves.”  

I slip the brass token into my fist and murmur to Jory, “You know any other way into the annex—service hatch, vent, anything—so we don’t walk right under their eyes?”
messages.player_reasoning: Those watchers feel like Harrow or Tideglass, and the towed/hand-carried thing could be a weapon or kit. I’m not built to win a straight confrontation; I need to ghost past and get eyes on the annex door, using height and timing with the bell signal.

messages.content:
Jory drops with you into a crouch, shoulders tucked under the catwalk rail. Your grip on him is firm enough that he doesn’t argue—just breathes out once, slow, and follows your lead.

Up here the metal is slick with fog-sweat; your palm smears cold moisture along the grated floor. West, Pole 48 is a pale vertical ghost through sodium haze, and beyond it the pump house bulk sits low and black, like a squat tooth on the edge of Pier Nine.

Below, the two raincoats pause. One raises a hand—two fingers, quick—then both shift position so they’re no longer directly under the camera dome. They’re working angles, not patrolling. The one who’d been carrying the wheeled thing sets it down behind a reefer stack: a hard case, long enough to be a rifle bag or a tool kit.

Jory watches them, jaw tight. “That’s Authority-adjacent,” he whispers. “Compliance or Harrow’s plainclothes. Union doesn’t stash a case like that—they want you to *see* the threat.”

You ask about another way in. He nods toward the pump house roofline. “Annex has a service vent on the sea-facing side—old intake for the pumps. Grate’s bolted, but the bolts are soft from salt. If we stay high, there’s a maintenance run along the catwalk that crosses above the pump house yard. We can drop behind the building instead of walking under Pole 48.”

The buoy bell holds steady for two beats—then *skips* again, early and sharp.

At the same moment, one of the raincoats tilts their head like they’ve gotten a message. Their gaze lifts—almost to your catwalk—then slides away, not quite finding you. “They’re keyed to the bell,” Jory breathes. “That skip was a ‘move’ call.”

Far behind you, deeper in the container maze, the sweep noise swells: boots on metal stairs, a radio squawk, and Rook’s voice cutting off mid-sentence like someone finally pulled rank on him.

You’ve got a narrow window: high route to the pump house backside, watchers shifting below, and Harrow’s people closing the gap from the rear.

**Status updates:** Watchers repositioning; case stashed  
**Status updates:** Alternate route: rear vent intake  
**Status updates:** Harrow sweep pushing closer

I squeeze Jory’s shoulder once. “Rear vent. Now.”

I keep low and move fast along the maintenance run, eyes flicking between the pump house roofline and the catwalk behind us. “If they spot us, you keep moving—don’t stop to explain.”

When we reach the drop point, I whisper, “You go down first, check the yard. If it’s clear, wave me in—then we get those salt-soft bolts off that grate and disappear.”
messages.player_reasoning: The watchers are keyed to the bell and Harrow’s sweep is closing; going under Pole 48 risks a direct intercept. The high route to the rear vent is our best shot to avoid eyes and get into the annex fast, even if it’s messy.

messages.content:
Jory nods once—no wasted motion—and you both flow along the maintenance run, bodies flattened to the grated steel. The catwalk trembles faintly under your weight, cold water beading on the rail and dripping into the fog below.

**Immediate outcome:** you make it past the sightline of Pole 48 without being made.

Ahead, the pump house yard opens up as a darker rectangle in the haze, fenced with chain-link and topped with lazy coils of rusted wire. The annex squats off the pump house’s west flank—same concrete, newer steel door, no markings. Sea-side, you can just make out the intake vent: a rectangular grate half-hidden behind a salt-bleached stack of pallets.

Jory reaches the drop point first and swings a leg over, lowering himself down the ladder with the same quiet control. He pauses near the bottom, listening—then steps off into the yard shadow.

For two long seconds you only hear the buoy bell and the distant hum of reefer fans.

Then Jory crouches and lifts a hand in a tight, low wave: **clear—mostly.** He points, two fingers, toward the far corner by the fence line.

A shape is there—someone slumped against the chain-link, hood up, not moving right. Not dead, you think; breathing shallow, like they’re trying not to be heard. A Harbor Authority lanyard catches a smear of light when they shift. Jory mouths up at you: “Inspector’s aide… or a runner.”

Behind you on the catwalk, a radio squawks closer than before, and boots hit metal—Harrow’s sweep entering the reefer lane. A beam of light knifes through fog and briefly paints the underside of your maintenance run.

Jory whispers up, urgent: “Drop now. If they flood the yard with light, we’re pinned. Vent bolts are soft—give me thirty seconds and something to lever with.”

The air down there tastes like wet concrete and old brine; the pump house wall sweats salt in pale streaks. The slumped figure by the fence lets out a small, involuntary cough and clamps a hand over their mouth, eyes wide in the dark.

**Status updates:** Reached pump house yard unseen  
**Status updates:** Harrow sweep entering reefer lane  
**Status updates:** Unknown Authority runner in yard

I drop down into the yard and press in close to the pump house wall. “Jory—take this,” I whisper, sliding my folding knife into his hand for leverage, then I angle toward the slumped Authority runner, palm up in a calming gesture. “Hey—stay quiet and you keep breathing. Who are you, and are you hurt?”
messages.player_reasoning: We’re seconds from being lit up from above; vent is our quiet entry, but the slumped runner could blow us or be useful. I’ll drop, give Jory a tool, and quickly assess/silence-help the runner without getting stuck.

messages.content:
You drop into the yard and flatten to the pump house wall; the concrete is slick and cold, sweating salt. Jory catches your folding knife by the handle without looking, then crab-walks to the sea-facing intake vent, putting his shoulder between you and the yard’s open angles.

**Immediate outcome:** the runner doesn’t bolt or shout—your calm hand and low voice keep them pinned to silence.

Up close, the slumped figure is younger than you first clocked—late twenties, maybe. Harbor Authority lanyard, yes, but the badge is turned inward like they’ve been trying to hide it. Their lips are blue from cold and fear; one sleeve is dark-wet at the ribs.

They nod once, shallow, and whisper so softly you have to lean in. “M-Myra Venn. Records… Harrow’s annex clerk.” Their eyes flick past you to the foggy yard gate. “I’m hurt. Not bad-bad. Just… leaking.” A wince. “They’re purging. Tonight. Anyone who touched the accident tags.”

From the reefer lane side, a flashlight beam sweeps the fence line, then slides away—someone searching by habit rather than certainty. Boots clank on metal somewhere beyond the chain-link, closer than before.

Myra swallows and adds, voice shaking. “The tags… they’re pre-stamped. Time-of-death comes from a Tideglass ledger. Harrow’s people don’t write it—they *receive* it.” She fumbles inside her coat but stops when you tense. “I’ve got proof. Carbon copy. It’s… in my bra. I couldn’t—” Her breath hitches. “Don’t let them take me back in there.”

Jory works the vent grate bolts with your knife as a lever—metal squeals once, small and sharp, then he freezes, listening. He shifts his grip, slower. The first bolt gives with a soft crunch of corroded threads.

A faint cough echoes from the reefer lane—someone close, trying to be quiet and failing.

Jory murmurs without turning his head, “Grate’s coming. Two more bolts. Keep her quiet.”

**Status updates:** Myra identified; wounded  
**Status updates:** Harrow sweep near fence line  
**Status updates:** Vent grate loosening

I press two fingers to Myra’s sleeve at the ribs, feeling for how bad the leak is, then lean in close. “Myra—look at me. You’re coming with us. Keep your mouth shut and breathe through your nose, alright?”  

I glance to Jory. “How long?”  

Then back to Myra, low and firm. “The proof—slide it out to me, now, quick. No digging, no drama. If you can’t, you tell me where it is and we move.”
messages.player_reasoning: Myra’s bleeding and terrified; I need her quiet and mobile, and we need that proof without wasting time. Harrow’s people are close, so I’ll prioritize getting everyone through the vent and only grab what we can fast.

messages.content:
Your two fingers press into the wet fabric at Myra’s ribs—warmth under the cold, and a sticky drag that says it’s more than a scrape. Not a gush, but steady. When you catch her gaze and tell her to breathe through her nose, she actually does it: short, controlled pulls, jaw clenched to keep the pain quiet.

Fog beads on the chain-link behind her; somewhere beyond it, a flashlight beam slides past like a slow blade, then fades.

Jory doesn’t look up from the vent. He answers through his teeth, working the knife carefully so it won’t squeal again. “Bolt’s off. One more. Ten seconds if nobody shines a light on me.”

Myra swallows at your demand for the proof. “Okay—okay.” She brings her hands in tight to her chest, moving with the small, practiced economy of someone trying not to look like they’re doing anything. She pinches at the inside of her coat, then slips two fingers down her neckline just enough to hook paper.

For a heartbeat it catches—she winces, eyes watering—then she slides out a folded, damp carbon sheet and presses it into your palm.

Ink has bled but it’s legible in patches: **HARBOR AUTHORITY INCIDENT TAG — ACCIDENTAL DROWNING**… and beneath that, a typed time-of-death that makes your stomach tighten—**a timestamp in the next tide window**, not the last. In the margin, a clerk’s notation: **“Received per Tideglass schedule / Pier Nine convergence.”**

From the reefer lane, the cough comes again—closer—and you hear the soft clack of a radio handset being raised, someone about to speak.

Jory’s last bolt gives with a muted crunch. He eases the grate free just enough to make a dark mouth in the wall, cold air breathing out of it like a cellar.

“Now,” he whispers. “One at a time.”

**Status updates:** Vent opening accessible

I fold the damp carbon copy tight and stuff it inside my jacket, then grab Myra under the arm. “You first—now. Crawl in and don’t stop, no matter what you hear.”  

I glance at Jory. “Get in behind her; I’m last—give me my knife back once you’re through.”  

As Myra starts into the dark, I keep my body between the yard and the vent mouth, listening for that radio to key up and ready to shove us all inside if a light hits the wall.
messages.player_reasoning: Searchers are seconds away; the proof is in hand and the vent is open. Myra’s bleeding but mobile, so I need to get her through first while Jory covers the opening, then follow and pull the grate back into place as best we can.

messages.content:
**IMMEDIATE OUTCOME:** Myra gets into the vent and disappears into the dark without a sound; Jory follows tight behind her. You hold the yard side long enough to keep the opening unlit—then the sweep’s light finally catches the wall, and you have to commit.

The vent mouth is at your right shoulder, cut into the pump house’s sea-facing wall; cold, damp air breathes out of it, smelling of rust, algae, and old machine oil. Your back is to the concrete, body angled to block the opening.

Myra’s shoes scrape faintly on metal inside, then stop—she whispers back, barely audible, “There’s a drop—ladder—” and then she clamps down, obeying you. Jory’s silhouette vanishes after her; before he goes fully in, he presses your folding knife back into your palm, handle-first, and murmurs, “Grate’ll hang—don’t slam it.”

From the reefer lane, the radio finally keys: a harsh, clipped voice. “Unit Two, check the pump yard. Thought I saw movement by the fence.” Boots shift direction—closer, purposeful now.

A flashlight beam washes over the chain-link and slides onto the pump house wall. It climbs—slow—like someone searching for edges and gaps. When it nears your position, you feel the salt-dry on your lips, that familiar metallic brine-taste of trouble rising.

Jory hisses from inside, urgent but controlled: “Rafe—now.”

You shove into the vent after them, shoulders scraping, and hook the grate as you go so it settles back into place without a clang. Outside, the beam lingers on the wall for a second longer, then drifts on—missing the vent by inches.

Inside, the vent narrows into a maintenance crawl with wet metal ribs. Ahead, Myra’s breathing is the only steady thing.

**Status updates:** Knife recovered  
**Status updates:** Sweep checking pump yard

I keep my voice down to a breath. “Good—keep crawling. Myra, don’t look back.”  

I slide forward and reach out to catch her boot/ankle gently. “You said ladder—how far? Tell me before you go over.”  

To Jory, a whisper like a knife edge: “Once we hit the drop, you take point and find the annex side. I’ll bring the grate back into place if it shifts—then we move.”
messages.player_reasoning: We’re in a tight crawl with a wounded clerk and a pursuer outside; I need to keep them moving quietly, control the drop she mentioned, and get us deeper before anyone thinks to check the vent.

messages.content:
**IMMEDIATE OUTCOME:** Your hand finds Myra’s ankle before she reaches the edge; she halts hard, catching herself with a stifled gasp instead of tumbling into the drop. The noise is small—but in a metal throat like this, it carries.

The crawlspace runs straight inland under the pump house, ribs of corroded sheet metal pressing close on both sides. Condensation drips from a seam above your left shoulder, tapping your knuckles like a slow metronome.

Myra freezes at your grip. In a breath-thin whisper: “Three feet. Then it opens—vertical service shaft. Ladder’s bolted to the right wall. Missing rungs near the bottom.” She swallows, forcing the rest out. “It drops into the annex intake corridor. You’ll hear the pumps change pitch when you’re close.”

Jory edges up behind her, shoulders hunched, eyes reflecting faint light from somewhere below. “Annex side, yeah,” he murmurs. “But Harrow’s got people in there sometimes. If we hear voices, we hold on the ladder—don’t drop into the corridor blind.”

Above and behind you, from the yard side, the flashlight beam briefly skates across the vent grate. The metal vibrates—just a tremor—as if someone’s gloved knuckles tested it and moved on. A radio crackles, muffled by walls: “Negative—nothing in the pump yard. Keep sweeping.”

The grate doesn’t shift, but you feel how close that was.

Myra starts to move again, carefully. You keep your palm at her boot long enough to guide her to the lip. The air coming up from the shaft is colder and wetter, carrying a faint chemical bite—bleach or solvent—like someone cleaned something recently.

**Status updates:** Drop located; fall prevented  
**Status updates:** Yard sweep moving on  
**Status updates:** Annex corridor nearby

I press my forehead to the cold metal for a beat, listening down the shaft for voices or footsteps. “Myra—hands on the right wall, find the ladder, one rung at a time. If it hurts, you tell me, not the dark.”  

I whisper to Jory, “You first—quiet as prayer. Stop before the missing rungs and listen over the pump noise; if it’s clear, you tap the pipe twice.”  

I keep one hand on Myra’s belt/back of her coat as she starts down, the other ready with my knife, and I glance back once toward the grate like it might breathe.
messages.player_reasoning: The shaft is a choke point and Myra’s hurt; I need to keep her steady and avoid dropping into a possibly occupied corridor. I’ll listen first, then get Jory on the ladder to scout while I manage Myra and watch our back.

messages.content:
**IMMEDIATE OUTCOME:** You catch it—no voices, no footsteps below, just the steady churn of pumps and the faint, wet tick of dripwater… until a soft *clink* answers from somewhere down the shaft, like metal lightly kissed by metal. Not a pump sound. Something small and deliberate.

Your forehead rests against the shaft’s lip; the metal is cold enough to sting. The drop opens beneath you like a throat, air rising in damp pulses. To your right, the ladder is there—bolted into the wall, slick with condensation.

Myra nods without looking back, jaw tight. “Okay,” she breathes, and does exactly what you told her: palms to the right wall, fingers finding the ladder’s side rail. When she shifts her weight onto the first rung, pain flashes across her face—she swallows it down, then forces out, “It—pulls. But I’m good.” She’s trying to be brave and it’s costing her.

Jory slips past, moving with dock-bred economy. He goes first, boots landing on rungs like he’s placing them on glass. Halfway down, he stops—right where the air changes, where the pump noise deepens and the chemical-clean bite strengthens. He leans his head, listening.

Above, behind you, the vent grate gives a tiny shiver—barely a vibration—like the wall remembered it was hollow. No flashlight now, no radio, but the yard isn’t *gone*; it’s just moved, and sound carries weird in fog.

Below, Jory raises his hand and holds it still. Then: a muted scrape, not from him—lower, off to the side, like someone shifting on concrete in the corridor beyond the shaft opening.

He doesn’t tap twice. He doesn’t move. He looks up at you, eyes narrowed, and whispers, “Not clear.”

Myra freezes mid-ladder, breath caught. Her injured side trembles with the effort of holding still.

**Status updates:** Shaft not clear below  
**Status updates:** Annex corridor occupied (unknown)  
**Status updates:** Myra stable, in pain

I go still, one hand firm on Myra’s coat. “Myra—lock your elbows, breathe through your nose. Don’t move unless I tell you.”

I lean down toward Jory, barely a whisper. “How many? Where’s the scrape—left or right of the shaft?”

Then I angle my mouth toward the opening below and murmur in a flat, official tone, “Maintenance—clear the corridor. Chemical line check.” I keep my knife tight to my thigh, ready to climb back up fast if the grate rattles again.
messages.player_reasoning: Someone’s waiting below, and Myra can’t hang on the ladder long. I need to keep them silent, avoid a confrontation in the open shaft, and gather intel fast—use sound and a bluff if necessary while preparing to retreat upward if the grate gets tested again.

messages.content:
**IMMEDIATE OUTCOME:** Your “Maintenance” voice buys you half a second—then the corridor answers wrong.

A man’s voice carries up from below, close enough that he’s either under the shaft or just past its mouth: “Maintenance doesn’t come in through vents.” Calm, amused. “And nobody says ‘chemical line check’ unless they’re reading it off a clipboard.”

Jory keeps one hand clamped on the ladder rail, knuckles white. He whispers up, barely moving his mouth: “One. Maybe two. Scrape was right side—like a boot toe pivoting. He’s close. Not Union. Too clean.”

Myra locks up like you told her—elbows rigid, breath pulled thin through her nose. You can feel the tremor in her coat where your hand holds her. She forces out, almost silent: “Rafe… I can’t hang forever.”

The air down the shaft tastes sharper now—bleach and something metallic—like recent cleanup over old rust. Below, a small light clicks on, not a flashlight beam sweeping, but a tight, controlled glow angled *up* the ladder: it catches Jory’s boots and the underside of the rungs, turning the condensation into glittering needles.

The voice again, a little louder, still even: “Back out. Slow. Nobody gets hurt. I just need the clerk.”

At the same moment, above and behind you, the vent grate gives another faint vibration—followed by the soft *tink* of a fastener being touched. Someone is back at the yard side, quieter than the first patrol.

Jory swallows and adds, urgent: “Rafe—if he’s Authority, he’ll call it in. If he’s Tideglass… he won’t.”

**SENSORY:** Cold metal bites your cheek; below, the pump thrum masks footsteps until they’re already close.

**STATUS UPDATES:** Corridor contact: confirmed voice  
**STATUS UPDATES:** Yard side: someone at grate  
**STATUS UPDATES:** Myra: strain increasing

I inhale slow, keep my voice steady down the shaft. “Alright. Easy. Don’t point that light in our eyes and nobody falls.”

I whisper to Jory, tight: “When he steps under the mouth, kill the light—kick him back. I’m dropping on him.” Then to Myra, softer but firm: “Hold. Two breaths. Then you move when I move.”

I shift my weight to the ladder, knife clenched but tucked, and call down again, coaxing: “You want the clerk? Step closer so I can hand her down—she’s hurt.”
messages.player_reasoning: We’re pinched top and bottom; talking won’t save us, but buying seconds might. I’d rather gamble on the corridor guy than let whoever’s at the grate trap us. I’ll bluff compliance, get the corridor man under the shaft, then drop him hard and push through with Jory while Myra’s still holding on.

messages.content:
**IMMEDIATE OUTCOME:** Your coax works—too well.

The tight light below tilts away from Jory’s face, then inches closer to the shaft mouth like it’s being carried in a careful hand. The voice stays level. “Hand her down, then you. Slow.”

A shape moves into the spill of its own light: not a uniformed Authority officer—no badge flash, no cap—but a rain-dark coat, clean boots, and hands in thin gloves. He steps under the mouth far enough that his head and shoulders are directly beneath Jory’s boots.

Jory reacts on instinct and training. He snaps his heel out—hard—catching the light source. It isn’t a flashlight; it’s a small inspection lamp on a short handle. It clatters off the concrete and spins into shadow, plunging the shaft into pump-lit dimness.

The man below grunts, rocked back a half step. Jory drives a second kick into his chest/shoulder line—enough to break his balance, not enough to launch him. That’s your window.

You shift onto the ladder and drop your weight down fast, controlled—forearms tight, knife pinned to your thigh so it doesn’t snag. You hit him with a shoulder-and-hip check as he stumbles, both of you slamming into the right wall of the corridor with a wet clang. He’s solid, stronger than he looks, and he immediately tries to turn you into the wall and pin your knife arm.

Above, Myra holds for two breaths like you said—then her injured side gives a sharp tremor and she whimpers, biting it off. She starts to descend on your movement, one rung at a time, but she’s shaking.

Behind you—up at the vent—metal whispers again: a fastener finally loosening, a faint scrape like a screwdriver turning slow. Whoever’s on the yard side is committing now.

The man you tackled hisses in your ear, breath steady despite the hit: “Calder. Of course.” His gloved fingers probe for your wrist. “They said you’d come through the intake.”

**SENSORY GROUNDING:** You’re in the annex intake corridor at the base of the shaft; the wall is cold, wet-painted metal, smelling of bleach over rust.

**STATUS UPDATES:** Corridor contact: engaged, pinned close  
**STATUS UPDATES:** Shaft above: Myra descending, unstable  
**STATUS UPDATES:** Yard side: grate being opened

I bare my teeth close to his ear. “Yeah—well, they didn’t say I bite.” I slam my forehead into his nose and use the moment to wrench my knife hand free, driving my shoulder under his arm to break the pin.  

Without looking up, I bark low, “Jory—catch Myra. Now.” Then I shove the man hard toward the corridor’s right side, trying to put him between us and the shaft mouth, and growl, “Who sent you—Tideglass or Harrow?”
messages.player_reasoning: He knows my name and someone’s opening the grate—this is a setup. I need to keep Myra from falling, keep Jory in the fight, and get this guy off-balance without flashing the knife yet.

messages.content:
Your forehead drives into his face with a meaty crack. He jerks back, nose instantly wet and hot; his grip loosens just enough for you to wrench your knife-side free and dip your shoulder under his arm. The pin breaks—clean—turning his leverage into empty air.

You shove him hard toward the corridor’s right wall. He stumbles, catches himself on a conduit, and for a beat he’s exactly what you wanted: a body between you and the shaft mouth.

Jory moves the instant you bark it. He climbs down two rungs fast, then reaches up and catches Myra under the arms as her injured side buckles. Her boot skids on a rung; Jory grunts, absorbing her weight, and drags her the last step down into the corridor. Myra’s breathing goes thin and angry, but she stays conscious.

The man wipes at his nose with the back of his glove, smearing blood. In the pump-dim he tilts his head like he’s listening to something you can’t hear—then answers your growl with a low, humorless exhale.

“Harrow doesn’t send me,” he says. “Harrow cleans up after.” His eyes flick up the shaft, then back to you. “And Tideglass doesn’t *hire*—they *name*.”

He shifts his stance sideways, right hand dropping toward his coat pocket like there’s a tool there, not a gun. “I’m here because the intake was breached and the clerk went missing from Records. I was told Calder would be part of it. I’m trying to keep this from becoming another ‘accident’ tag.”

Above you, the vent grate finally gives—just a fraction. A cold ribbon of fog spills through the gap, carrying a faint, sweet-copper smell… and the soft rasp of someone’s breath controlling itself.

**SENSORY GROUNDING:** You’re pressed in the annex intake corridor at the base of the shaft; bleach-stung air, wet-painted metal under your palms, pump thrum vibrating your teeth.

I keep my knife low but visible and flick two fingers at Jory. “Get Myra behind that conduit bend—down and quiet.”

Without taking my eyes off the bleeding man, I raise my voice just enough toward the shaft. “Hey—up there. Don’t come down. There’s no oxygen for heroics in this hole.” Then, to the man in front of me, cold: “Take your hand out of your pocket—slow. Who ‘told’ you Calder would be here, and what name did Tideglass put on me?”
messages.player_reasoning: The grate is opening—immediate threat above. The man below might be a lead, but his pocket move could turn lethal. I need to secure Myra, control both angles, and extract info fast without escalating into a firefight in a tight corridor.

messages.content:
Jory reads your two-finger flick like a drill command. He half-drags, half-carries Myra around the conduit bend to your left—out of the shaft’s line and out of the corridor’s center. Myra sinks to a crouch with her back to the cold metal, one hand clamped to her side, breathing through her teeth to stay quiet.

Your warning up the shaft lands. The vent gap stops widening for a beat—then whoever’s up there lets out a thin, controlled exhale you can hear through the fog ribbon. No boots hit the ladder. Not yet.

The bleeding man’s eyes track your knife and the bend where Myra disappeared. When you tell him to take his hand out slow, he does—empty palm first—then the other hand follows, bringing out a flat, black tool case no bigger than a paperback. He sets it on the wet floor and nudges it away with his boot like he’s trying to prove he’s not reaching for a weapon.

“Name’s Vell,” he says, voice tight now that his nose is pouring. “Marn Vell. Night auditor. Not patrol.” He touches the bridge of his nose and winces. “And the one who ‘told’ me was Deputy Hume’s office—schedule sheet. Not a whisper. A written expectation.”

At “what name did Tideglass put on me,” his gaze flicks to the brass buoy-bell token if it’s anywhere visible, then back to your face like he’s weighing how much truth costs.

“They don’t use your first name,” Vell says. “They use *ledger names*. Bloodline marks. You’re listed as **Calder / Owed / Returned**—same wording that’s been showing up on memorial programs and incident tags. It’s not a threat in their language. It’s… a claim already filed.”

Above, the vent grate gives a soft metallic click as it shifts another fraction—just enough to let a fingertip in. Fog spills thicker, and with it comes a faint scrape like someone testing the edge of the opening with something hard.

Vell keeps his hands visible, but his shoulders angle subtly—protective, like he expects the next hit to come from above, not you. “If they get you to say your full name near a buoy or a memorial bell,” he adds, “it goes bad fast. Don’t. Not tonight.”

**SENSORY GROUNDING:** Base of the intake shaft; conduit bend left, corridor right; bleach-stung damp air and pump vibration underfoot.

**STATUS UPDATES:** Myra: concealed, crouched  
**STATUS UPDATES:** Vent: gap widening slowly  
**STATUS UPDATES:** Vell: identified, hands shown

My throat tightens at “Owed / Returned,” but I keep my face flat. “Good. Then keep your mouth shut about names,” I murmur, then flick my eyes up at the vent.  

I raise my voice toward the grate, sharp and official. “Don’t. Whatever you think you’re walking into—back off. There’s a knife and a fall waiting.”  

To Vell, low and fast, I jerk my chin at the tool case. “Slide that to me. Then tell me where Records is from here and why Hume’s office wanted you in my path.”
messages.player_reasoning: That ledger-name hits too close to home; I don’t trust Vell, but the bigger threat is the grate opening above. I need to stop whoever’s coming through, keep Myra quiet, and get something useful out of Vell fast.

messages.content:
I keep my knife low and steady, eyes flicking once to the vent. “Up there—back off. Next move is a fall,” I call, flat and official.  
Then I angle the blade toward Vell’s feet. “Slide the case to me. Now—where’s Records from here, and why did Hume’s office put you in my lane?”
messages.player_reasoning: That ledger-name hits too close; I can’t let anyone up top force a confrontation, and I need leverage and directions fast—tool case first, then answers.

messages.content:
Your voice carries up the shaft like a baton crack. The vent grate freezes mid-shift—whoever’s up there stops pushing. Fog still dribbles through the thin gap, but the scraping sound cuts off, replaced by a held-breath silence.

Vell’s eyes flick up once, then back to your knife. He lowers his heel to the tool case and nudges it forward. The plastic skates over the wet concrete, bumps your boot, and stops. He keeps both hands up and open.

“You want Records from here?” he says, fast and clipped. “You don’t go back out the annex door. There’s a service corridor behind that conduit bend—past your clerk—leads to the old archive cage. Down a half-flight, then a card-locked door with a brass plate that still says *FILES* even though they renamed it ‘Compliance.’ Myra can get you through if she’s got her badge. If she doesn’t—someone in Hume’s office *revoked* her access this afternoon.”

Behind the bend, Myra makes a small, strangled sound—half protest, half confirmation—then forces it quiet.

“As for why Hume put me in your lane,” Vell continues, swallowing around the blood in his nose, “because I’m the one who signs off on ‘late’ incident tags when Harrow’s people need them to look clean. Hume’s office told me: *go to the intake, confirm breach, confirm Calder present, and call it in.* That’s not an audit. That’s a setup. They wanted a witness who can turn you into a line item.”

The pump thrum under your feet deepens for a second—like the system pulling harder—then steadies again. Somewhere above, a faint *tick…tick* answers from the vent, metal on metal, careful and patient, like someone repositioning a tool without committing to the drop.

Vell leans his head slightly toward the shaft without taking his eyes off you. “If they’re up there with a hook,” he murmurs, “they’re not here for me.”

**SENSORY GROUNDING:** Intake corridor at the base of the vertical shaft; conduit bend to your left hides Myra and the service corridor entrance; fog threads down from the vent gap above.

**STATUS UPDATES:** Tool case: at your feet  
**STATUS UPDATES:** Vent intruder: paused, listening  
**STATUS UPDATES:** Myra access: possibly revoked

I toe the tool case behind my heel and scoop it up without looking, keeping my knife trained on Vell. “You don’t call this in,” I say, low. “Not to Hume, not to Harrow—nobody. You want to live through tonight, you didn’t see me.”

I glance around the conduit bend. “Myra—badge. Now. Can you still open FILES?” Then up toward the vent, I snap, “Last warning—back off, or I start cutting rungs and we all drop together.”
messages.player_reasoning: Hume’s setting me up means time’s poison; the vent intruder feels like the real blade. I need to secure the tool case, get Myra moving toward Records, and keep Vell from calling anything in—without turning him into an enemy.

messages.content:
The tool case disappears into your grip clean—no fumble, no clack. Vell sees it go and gives a tight, jerky nod like you just took the only thing that could get him killed faster. He doesn’t reach for anything, doesn’t even wipe his nose; he just keeps his hands up and his voice down.

“I won’t call,” he says. “Not Hume. Not Harrow. I’m done being the pen.”

Around the conduit bend, Myra drags her badge lanyard up with shaking fingers. In the spill of gray light it flashes Harbor Authority blue, but the corner’s been punched—an old deactivation mark. She swallows, eyes wet with pain and fury.

“I can *try*,” she whispers. “They flagged me at shift change. Door might still take it if the panel’s not been updated tonight. If it’s live-locked, we need a supervisor override… or we rip the reader and jump the strike.”

Up at the vent, your threat lands harder. There’s a soft, involuntary *tap*—metal kissing metal—then a quick retreating scrape as whatever was prying the grate pulls back. Not gone, but repositioning. A second later, a muffled voice filters down through the narrow gap, distorted by the shaft:

“Calder. Don’t make it worse.”

It’s not Vell. Not Myra. And it says your name like it’s reading it off a form.

The pump’s vibration shifts again—briefly stronger, like a surge—sending a cold shiver through the ladder rungs. Moisture beads on the metal and runs in thin lines toward the drain, making everything slicker than it was a minute ago.

Vell’s eyes cut sideways toward the service corridor entrance. “FILES is where the tag templates are,” he adds, urgent. “If you’ve got a carbon copy with a future time, the matching originals will be in there—unless Harrow already had them pulled for the sweep.”

**SENSORY GROUNDING:** Base of the intake shaft; conduit bend left (Myra, service corridor); ladder and vent above, fog seeping down.

**STATUS UPDATES:** Myra badge: likely deactivated  
**STATUS UPDATES:** Vent watcher: repositioned, spoke your name

I lift my chin toward the vent, voice like rebar. “Say my name again and I start breaking things you need intact—back off.”  
Then I crouch by Myra, pushing the tool case into her hands. “Open it—tell me what it is. If your badge fails, we’re ripping the reader; you walk me through it.”  
I glance at Vell, knife still low but ready. “You’re coming—hands where I can see. You try to ‘be the pen’ again, I cut it out of you. Move.”
messages.player_reasoning: Someone above knows my name and is trying to control the situation; I need to get Myra moving toward FILES while keeping Vell from becoming a liability, and I want to see what’s in the tool case in case it helps with the door.

messages.content:
Your threat hits the vent like a thrown wrench. The grate gives a tiny, involuntary rattle—then stillness. No answer this time. Just the faintest drag of fabric retreating along the ducting, careful not to scrape.

You drop beside Myra and shove the tool case into her hands. She pops the latches with practiced fingers—too practiced for a “records clerk”—and the lid springs open on foam cutouts: a Harbor Authority tag-stamp kit, blank “ACCIDENT / HARBOR AUTHORITY” toe tags, a small ink pad still wet, and a narrow punch that matches the deactivation hole in her badge.

Myra’s face goes pale with a kind of clarity. “This is… this is how they’re doing it fast,” she whispers. “Prepped tags. Portable stamp. You can print a time and make it look filed before the body even surfaces.” She looks up at you. “This isn’t Compliance. This is Harrow’s sweep team.”

Vell flinches when you order him to move. He obeys—hands high, shoulders tight—sliding in behind you and Myra like he’s trying not to exist. “I told you,” he says through his teeth. “Hume’s office wanted you on paper. This—this is the paper.”

You angle toward the service corridor. The air changes immediately: less open fog, more hot electrical breath from the conduit run; the floor is slick with condensation and something oily near the wall plates.

Myra wipes her palm on her skirt and holds her badge like a prayer. “If the reader’s been updated tonight, it’ll hard-deny me. If it hasn’t… it might still chirp green. If we rip it, we need two wires—power and strike—and we need to do it quiet. The corridor carries sound.”

Above, the pump vibration surges again, a low mechanical groan that travels up the ladder rungs—like the building itself is bracing. Somewhere in the ductwork, a soft *thunk* answers: not a voice, not yet, but weight shifting into a better position.

**SENSORY GROUNDING:** You’re at the conduit bend; service corridor mouth ahead-left, vent shaft behind and above, fog threading down.

I take the punch tool from the kit and slip it into my pocket, then press two fingers under Myra’s chin to steady her. “Try the badge. One clean attempt—if it chirps red, we rip it and you talk me through the wires.”

I glance back at the shaft, then to Vell. “You’re first through the door when it opens—hands on your head. If the vent voice drops in, you scream and you hit the deck.” I angle us toward the reader, knife low, and whisper to Myra, “On three.”
messages.player_reasoning: Harrow’s people are close and the vent watcher is repositioning; we need to get into FILES fast and quiet. Myra’s shaken but sharp—let her try the badge first, and keep Vell controlled as leverage and a guide.

messages.content:
Myra’s eyes lock onto yours when you steady her. The tremor in her hands doesn’t stop, but it narrows—like she’s forcing it into a single line of motion.

“One clean,” she echoes, and nods.

You slip the punch tool away. The foam in the case yawns where it was, a neat absence.

You stack up on the reader: corridor mouth at your left shoulder, intake shaft and its wet ladder behind you. The air here is warmer, tinged with ozone and old cleanser; a thin line of condensation runs down the wall into a floor drain that gurgles a beat behind the pump’s thrum.

“On three,” you whisper.

Myra lifts the badge. Vell goes rigid at your order—hands interlaced on top of his head, jaw clenched so hard it clicks. “I’m not your problem,” he mutters, then adds, quieter, “but they are.”

One… two… three.

Myra swipes.

The panel lights up—green for half a heartbeat—then snaps to a hard, ugly red. A buzzer chirps once, sharp as a gull cry, and the lock gives a refusal *clunk* that carries down the corridor like a dropped tool.

Above and behind, in the shaft, something shifts at speed—metal rings tick as weight hits the ladder. Not falling yet, but committing.

Myra flinches back from the reader, breath hitching. “They updated it,” she hisses. “Live lock. Okay—okay—don’t yank the whole box, you’ll trip an alarm line. We peel the faceplate, find the strike pair—usually blue-white—jump it just long enough to pop—”

Vell’s eyes go wide, and he does exactly what you told him: he sucks in air to scream, then throws himself flat, palms over his head.

The pump surges again, deeper this time, and the corridor lights stutter—once—like the building blinked.

**SENSORY GROUNDING:** You’re inches from the FILES/Compliance reader; intake shaft is behind you, service corridor ahead-left, slick floor underfoot.

I snap my knife up toward the shaft without turning fully. “Stay on that ladder and you keep your teeth—drop and I take the rungs with you.”  
Then I crouch tight to the reader with Myra. “Do it—talk me through. I’ll peel the faceplate; you point, I cut.” I palm the knife tip under the seam and start prying, keeping my shoulder between her and the shaft.  
To Vell, sharp: “Crawl to the far wall, stay flat, and shut up unless you see them.”
messages.player_reasoning: The vent watcher is moving now—if we don’t get through the door fast, we’ll be trapped between the shaft and a locked reader. Myra knows the wiring, so I’ll cover her and rush the quick bypass while keeping Vell from panicking into our way.

messages.content:
The knife comes up toward the shaft without you giving the watcher your back. Your voice—flat, steel—stops the movement for a beat.

Then the ladder *ticks* again: not a drop, but a careful descent, rung by rung, like whoever’s up there is testing how far your attention can be split.

You crouch into the reader with Myra. The knife tip finds the seam; the faceplate fights you with cheap adhesive and two hidden clips. You lever it—*crack*—and the plate pops loose enough to see the guts: a tight bundle of paired wires, a small tamper switch, and a thin alarm lead taped separately.

Myra leans in close to your shoulder, voice racing but precise. “Don’t cut—strip. If you cut the alarm lead, it’ll scream upstairs. See that little spring tab? That’s tamper.” She points with a shaking finger. “Hold it down with something non-metal if you can. The strike pair is—” she squints, breath catching as the corridor light stutters again—“blue and white, twisted. Power’s red-black. We only need to jump blue-white for a second.”

Vell obeys, belly-crawling to the far wall, palms sliding through condensation. He keeps his face turned toward the shaft, eyes huge. “I see—” he starts, then clamps his mouth shut, swallowing the rest.

Behind you, a shape becomes visible in the shaft’s mouth: a forearm in a dark rain sleeve, fingers pale and wet, gripping the ladder rail. Not uniform. Not Union orange. A ring glints once as it shifts—then the hand pauses, listening.

The pump’s groan deepens and holds, making the lock’s metal hum under your fingertips. Somewhere farther down the service corridor, a door closes softly—too soft to be accidental—followed by the faint click of a radio squelch.

**SENSORY GROUNDING:** You’re kneeling at the FILES/Compliance reader; shaft behind-right, corridor stretching ahead-left, floor slick under your knee.

I shove a folded edge of Myra’s lanyard strap against the tamper spring to keep it depressed, then hiss to her, “Blue-white—tell me when.” Without looking back, I bark up the shaft, “One more rung and I break your hand.”  
I strip a sliver of insulation off the blue-white pair with the knife tip and touch them together just long enough to pop the strike. “Vell—on green, you go.”
messages.player_reasoning: I need that door open fast, but if I trip tamper we’re cooked. I’ll keep the shaft watcher pinned with my voice while Myra guides the jump, using something non-metal to hold the tamper, and get Vell ready to bolt through first.

messages.content:
The folded lanyard edge bites into the tamper spring and holds. Myra sucks in a breath like she’s about to faint, then steadies when she feels the pressure stay consistent. “Now,” she whispers—barely audible over the pump.

You shave insulation off the blue-white twist with the knife tip and kiss copper to copper.

The lock answers with a sharp *clack* and a brief green blink—like a throat clearing—then the strike releases. The Compliance door pops inward a finger’s width.

Vell launches on that moment, scrambling up from his belly-crawl with hands still on his head, and slips through the crack sideways. He’s shaking so hard his shoulder bumps the jamb. “I’m going— I’m going—” he hisses, disappearing into the dim.

Behind you, the pale hand on the ladder freezes at your threat. For half a second it’s just skin and ring and wet sleeve. Then the fingers loosen silently and withdraw up into the shaft without a scrape, like it was never there.

Myra leans closer, eyes on the exposed wiring. “Don’t leave it jumped,” she warns. “If it stays bridged, the system logs it as a forced hold.” She swallows. “And Rafe—there’s a second alarm line sometimes, tied to the door contact. If it opens too far—”

Down the service corridor, the radio squelch clicks again, clearer now, and a man’s voice murmurs through it—words swallowed by distance, but the cadence is Authority. Footsteps answer: measured, not running, coming your way.

I break the blue-white contact immediately and shove the faceplate back on just enough to hide the mess, then grab Myra by the sleeve and pull her through the cracked door after Vell. “Door only opens a breath—move, don’t swing it,” I whisper, easing it shut behind us to just before latch, knife ready as I listen for the footsteps outside.

messages.content:
You break the blue-white contact cleanly; the green blink dies instantly. Myra’s lanyard slips free of the tamper spring and you press the faceplate back on—crooked, but flush enough that from the hall it reads “intact,” not “open surgery.”

You hook Myra by the sleeve and thread her through the Compliance door on the same narrow breath you kept it to. The hinges barely whisper. You ease it back toward the latch without letting it *click*—just shy of seated, so it looks closed but will give if you need to pull.

Inside FILES/Compliance, the air changes: dry paper-dust under the cleanser, warm electronics, and the faint metallic tang of old staples. Rows of gray cabinets and boxed ledgers crowd the room. A single desk lamp is on—low—like someone left in a hurry.

Vell is already in here, backed against a cabinet, hands still on his head like he forgot he’s allowed to stop. His eyes flick between you and the door crack. “They’re sweeping,” he whispers. “Not just this floor. I heard ‘Pier Nine’ on a radio earlier—before you got me.”

Myra leans in close, voice tight. “If that door contact is live, opening it again might flag the panel. We bought seconds, not safety.” She points—quick, precise—toward a wall-mounted compliance terminal with a card slot and a small status light. “That station can pull incident tags and audit logs if it’s still on the network. If Harrow’s people are here, they’ll want the same thing.”

Outside the door, the measured footsteps reach your side of the corridor and slow. A radio murmurs right on the other side—close enough you can hear the plastic click as someone keys it. The voice is calm, bored-professional: “Compliance corridor. Door reads secure.”

A second voice answers, nearer the intake side—faintly distorted, like speaking from inside a shaft: “Copy. Keep moving.”

The buoy-bell rhythm seems to echo in your teeth for a moment—off by a beat—then the building settles back into its mechanical hum.
