I press two fingers to my lips at Myra and Vell, then lean close to the door and listen until the footsteps fade a few paces. “Myra—get on that terminal, pull anything tied to Pier Nine, incident tags, audit logs… whatever names Harrow or Hume touches.”  

I slide to the cabinets, keeping my knife low, and whisper to Vell, “You said you heard Pier Nine—who said it? Any names, call signs?” Then I glance up at the vent lines in the ceiling. “And if that shaft voice comes back, we don’t talk to it—we move.”
messages.player_reasoning: Patrol is right outside and the door contact might be live, so I need silence and fast intel; the terminal is our best shot to learn what Harrow’s sweep is doing and why Pier Nine matters.

messages.content:
The patrol’s footsteps drift past the door and keep going—rubber soles on concrete, radio hiss trailing after them—until the corridor sound thins to the building’s steady hum. Nobody tests the handle.

Myra nods once at your signal and moves fast but careful to the compliance terminal. She swipes her clerk badge with a trembling hand; the status light flickers amber, then steadies. The screen blooms to a login prompt and she mutters, “Still on the network… okay… okay.” Her fingers fly. “If Harrow’s running a sweep, she’ll have a batch number. I can search by location and by authorizing officer—Harrow, Hume, Rook… but if they’ve already flagged this node, it’ll leave a footprint.”

You slide along the cabinets, knife low, watching the ceiling vent runs: rectangular ducting with three intake grilles. One grille’s screws are newer than the others—bright metal against old paint.

Vell licks salt off his lip like it’s been there awhile. “Two guys by the stairwell earlier. One said it—‘Pier Nine’—like a meet point. The other answered with a call sign… ‘Rook-Actual,’ I think. Or ‘Rook’ something.” He squeezes his eyes shut, forcing it back. “And—Hume. I heard Hume. Like, ‘Hume wants it clean before tide.’ I didn’t see their faces.”

The terminal gives a soft confirmation chime. Myra’s shoulders drop a fraction. “I’ve got incident tags indexed by berth and pier.” She glances over her shoulder at you. “Pier Nine has *fresh* entries—some stamped ‘ACCIDENT / FALL’—and the time-of-death fields… they’re wrong. Future wrong. Same pattern as Berth 12.”

From the vent line above, there’s a faint metallic *tick*—not loud, but too deliberate to be settling ductwork. Then silence, like someone holding their breath on the other side of sheet metal.

I tilt my head toward the vent screws, then quietly drag a filing cabinet drawer open a few inches—just enough to make a harsh scrape—watching the grille for a reaction.  

To Myra, low and urgent: “Screenshot, print-to-file, whatever you can—export those Pier Nine tags with the authorizer fields. Grab anything with Harrow, Hume, and ‘Rook-’ in it, then log out and pull the plug.”  

I lean to Vell, voice like a blade: “Rook-Actual… that’s not dock muscle. You hear ‘before tide’ again, you tell me immediately.” Then I shift under the vent line, knife ready, and whisper, “Myra—how long?”
messages.player_reasoning: The vent’s acting like it has eyes; I need to protect Myra while getting the key data fast. Pier Nine and “Rook-Actual” tie this to a coordinated cleanup, and the future TOD reeks of the curse—proof matters, but staying alive matters more.

messages.content:
The drawer scrape rips through the quiet like a saw on bone.

Above you, the vent grille answers immediately: a soft, panicked *skitter*—metal on metal—then a heavier *thunk* farther back in the duct, like someone jerked a knee or elbow off the sheet metal. Dust puffs from the seam of the newer screws. Whoever was up there just flinched hard.

Myra doesn’t look up; she just moves faster, jaw clenched. “Exporting,” she breathes, stabbing keys. The terminal whirs as she pulls Pier Nine incident tags with authorizer fields. On the screen you catch it: **ACCIDENT / FALL**, location **PIER 9**, authorizing chain including **Commissioner L. Harrow** on a batch approval, and a review stamp that reads **HUME, Compliance Liaison**. One entry flashes a user string: **D. ROOK — ACTUAL** in the audit trail, like a unit designation slotted into a name field.

A printer isn’t connected—just the terminal and a network line—so she dumps it to a local “TEMP EXPORT” directory and starts copying to whatever internal archive she can reach. “Thirty seconds,” she whispers back to you, “if it doesn’t hang. Then I’m logging out and yanking the cable.”

Vell’s eyes are fixed on the ceiling now, wide and wet. He nods hard at your warning, swallowing words he doesn’t trust himself with.

From the corridor outside, a radio chirps—closer again—followed by a pause like someone stopped walking. A hand brushes the Compliance door, not turning the knob, just *testing* the seam with fingertips. You feel it through the near-latched door: a faint vibration.

In the duct above, the silence turns deliberate—held—like the person up there is listening for your next breath.

I ease the Compliance door the last fraction until it *clicks* fully latched, then in a bored, official tone toward the hall: “Compliance is occupied—auditing exports. Come back with a warrant or a supervisor.”

messages.content:
Vell goes down behind the cabinets with a stifled grunt; your finger clamps his mouth and he nods fast, eyes huge, doing his best not to breathe loud.

You ease the Compliance door that last fraction. The latch *clicks*—clean, final. In the hall, the fingertip-testing stops.

Your bored, official tone carries through the seam: “Compliance is occupied—auditing exports. Come back with a warrant or a supervisor.”

A beat of radio hiss. Then a man answers, close enough to be right outside: “Copy that.” Not convinced—just contained. Footsteps shift, like he’s repositioning to the side of the door instead of leaving.

Myra’s hands keep moving. She whispers without turning, “Export’s done—copying the audit trail now.” The terminal makes a soft disk-chatter sound. On-screen, the “TEMP EXPORT” directory shows a timestamped bundle: **P9_TAGS_AUDIT**. Under it, the authorizer fields you wanted—Harrow batch approval, Hume review stamp, and that ugly **D. ROOK — ACTUAL** string in the access log.

Above you, the vent gives a faint, slow creak—as if weight is being shifted carefully. The newer screws on that grille tremble once, then go still.

The corridor presence doesn’t leave. You hear fabric brush concrete, a quiet exhale, and the tiny click of a radio being keyed but not spoken into—someone waiting for an excuse to escalate without being the one who “started it.”

Myra glances up just enough to catch your eye. “On your tap,” she says. “If I yank it mid-write, the file might corrupt—but the audit lines are already in the bundle.”

I tap Myra’s wrist twice. “Now—yank it.”  

As she does, I slide under the vent with my knife up and my other hand braced on the cabinet, whispering, “Vell—stay down. If that grille shifts, you crawl for the back wall and don’t look up.” Then, toward the door in that same bored voice, “Audit’s running. You open this door and it goes in the log with your badge number—your call.”
messages.player_reasoning: The hall officer is lingering and the vent listener is active; staying connected risks trace. I’ll cut the line now, then set an ambush posture—knife for the vent, body for the door—while quietly prepping an exit via cabinets/alternate route.

messages.content:
Myra flinches at your double-tap and yanks the network cable hard enough that the terminal jolts on its stand. The screen freezes mid-copy, then the connection icon dies. She immediately logs out anyway—muscle memory—and reaches under to kill the power strip. The room drops a shade darker as the monitor goes black.

Immediate effect: whatever was watching this node just lost its live feed.

In the same breath, the vent grille above you shifts—just a millimeter—then stops, like someone started to lift it and thought better. Your knife is already up. Dust sifts down onto your knuckles.

Vell’s eyes flick to the grille, but he obeys—stays low, shoulders hunched, beginning to inch toward the back wall without looking up.

Your bored warning toward the door lands. In the hall, the officer gives a short, humorless laugh. “Badge number?” he says, voice tightened. “Cute. This is a safety sweep. Doors open when we say.” But he still doesn’t hit the knob—yet. You hear him key his radio properly this time: “Rook-Actual, Compliance is dark. Possible tamper. I’m holding.”

That name carries through the door seam like cold water.

Above you, the duct answers with movement: a careful retreating scrape farther back, then a soft *clank* like a tool bumped metal. Whoever’s in the vents is repositioning, not fleeing—staying in the building.

Myra whispers, breath shaking, “I got the bundle created. If it wrote clean before the yank, it’ll be in TEMP on this machine. If not… it’s half a ghost.” She looks at the dead screen like it might accuse her.

**SENSORY GROUNDING:** FILES/Compliance—monitor now dark; you’re directly under the vent line, knife raised; the latched door is behind you with an officer posted outside.

I whisper to Myra, “Forget the screen—grab the drive if you can. Can you pull the storage out fast?” Then I tip my chin at the back wall, eyes still on the vent. “Find me another way out—service hatch, adjoining office, anything.”

To Vell, low: “Crawl to the back corner and stay put. If they come through that door, you don’t run—you freeze.”

I press my mouth close to the cabinet and call toward the hall, calm as paperwork: “Compliance terminal’s down. You force entry, you own the chain-of-custody break. I’m documenting it.” Then I shift a half-step under the vent, knife ready, listening for the grille to move again while I scan for a maintenance panel or secondary door.
messages.player_reasoning: We’re pinned between an armed “safety sweep” at the door and a vent intruder; staying here gets us boxed in when Rook-Actual arrives. I need an exit plan that doesn’t rely on that door, and I want the export bundle if it exists—but I won’t die for a maybe-file.

messages.content:
Myra nods once—sharp—and drops to her knees at the terminal stand. “It’s a thin client,” she whispers, fingers already under the casing. “If they did this right, the storage is local and stupid.” She pops two quarter-turn fasteners and slides a narrow drive caddy free with a metallic *snick*. “Got it.”

That tiny sound is enough.

In the vent above you, the grille shifts again—this time a decisive quarter-inch—and you hear the wet pop of pressure changing in the ductwork, like a lung clearing. The air that spills out is briny and cold. You instinctively brace a hand on the cabinet… and the concrete under your boot skates slick.

The vent *exhales*.

Mist slams into your face and knife hand. Your footing goes out hard; you hit a knee and palm, sliding toward the nearest floor drain as if the room has a gentle slope that wasn’t there a second ago. The drain grating suddenly sounds louder—closer—water gurgling like it’s being pulled somewhere deep. In the fog of salt, something catches your sleeve for a heartbeat—light, patient—tugging you another inch.

Vell freezes in the back corner like you told him, eyes squeezed shut, hands over his head.

Myra flattens herself beside the terminal stand, clutching the drive caddy to her chest. “Rafe—don’t fight it upright,” she hisses. “Crawl. The drains—” She points with two shaking fingers toward the back wall where heavy wall-bolts and conduit clamps run low: solid handholds.

Outside the Compliance door, the officer’s voice tightens at your chain-of-custody threat—then turns mean. “You’re already done,” he says. The knob tests once, hard, like he’s deciding whether to make the noise. In the hall, another set of steps arrives—he’s got company.

Through the thinning mist near the back wall you spot it: a rectangular maintenance panel half-hidden behind a filing shelf, painted the same gray as the wall, its screws old and scarred—**SERVICE CORRIDOR ACCESS** stenciled faintly under grime.

**SENSORY GROUNDING:** You’re down on slick concrete under the vent run; the floor drains are a few feet downslope; back wall bolts and conduit are within a crawl.

I grit my teeth and hook my fingers into the conduit clamps, hauling myself hand-over-hand away from the drain. “Myra—crawl to me. Keep that caddy under your shirt.”  

I snap at Vell without looking back, “Vell, move—now. Stay low, grab the bolts, follow my boots.”  

Then I slide to the SERVICE CORRIDOR panel, jam my knife tip under a screw head, and start prying. “If that door pops, we’re gone—no hero shit.”
messages.player_reasoning: The floor’s turning into a trap and the door’s about to get breached; the only play is low and fast to the service panel while keeping Myra and Vell alive, and I don’t trust the vent “breath” one inch.

messages.content:
Your fingers bite into the conduit clamps and you *crawl* instead of stand—ugly, effective. The drain’s pull fights for your ankles, but the clamps and wall-bolts give you purchase; you haul yourself hand-over-hand until the slope stops stealing you.

Myra scrapes after you on her forearms, face pale, shoving the drive caddy under her blouse like contraband. “It’s warm,” she whispers—more shock than comfort. “Like it was running a minute ago.”

Vell finally moves, low and shaking, gripping the bolts exactly where you told him, eyes locked on your boots as if they’re the only real thing in the room.

You get to the back-wall service panel and jam your knife tip under a screw head. The first pry slips—metal on metal—then catches. You lever hard; the screw gives with a sharp *crack* and the panel edge lifts enough to get your fingers in. Two more brutal tugs and the thin sheet-metal bows outward.

On the other side: a narrow, unlit service chase, smelling of dust, warm wiring, and old tide. It’s tight—shoulder-width—with a cable tray running low and a vertical drop-ladder bolted to the left wall.

In the hall, the Compliance door knob turns—tested again—then a heavy impact hits it once, like a shoulder check. The latch holds, but the frame groans. Over the radio you hear: “Rook-Actual says breach. Now.”

Above you, the vent grille shudders and a new sound joins the mist: a soft, rhythmic *tap… tap… tap* traveling along the duct toward your position, like someone using a tool to find the right spot to cut through.

Myra presses in close behind you, voice thin but focused. “That chase ties to the FILES corridor—if it’s not blocked. If they sealed it for the sweep, we’ll know fast.”

**SENSORY GROUNDING:** Back wall of FILES/Compliance—service panel peeled open; cold mist still curling from the vent behind you; the main door is across the room taking hits.

I shove the panel wider and grab Myra by the elbow. “Go. Down the ladder—don’t stop.”  

To Vell, sharp and low: “You’re right behind her. Hands on the rungs, eyes down.”  

I plant myself at the opening, knife up toward the vent, and call back into the room, “If that grille drops, I’m cutting you—try me,” then I slip into the chase last, yanking the panel in after us as much as it’ll close.
messages.player_reasoning: The door’s about to go and the vent’s being cut—staying in this room gets us pinned. The service chase is our only angle, and Myra’s carrying the only leverage we came for, so I need her moving first while I cover the rear for a heartbeat.

messages.content:
Myra goes when you shove her—no argument. She swings into the chase, finds the drop-ladder by touch, and starts down fast, one rung at a time, breath rasping. Vell nearly trips over her heels but catches himself and follows, knuckles white on the rungs, eyes pinned downward like you ordered.

You hold the opening, knife up toward the vent line. Your threat hangs in the mist.

The tapping in the duct stops.

For half a second there’s only the wet hiss of fog and the distant groan of the Compliance door taking another hit. Then—right above the vent grille—something *drags* across metal, slow and deliberate, as if whoever’s up there is choosing not to drop straight into your blade… and is instead moving to another cut point.

You slip in last and yank the service panel as closed as it’ll go. It doesn’t latch; it sits crooked, leaving a finger-width seam that leaks gray light from the Compliance room into the chase.

On the other side of that seam, the door finally gives: a crack of wood and a barked, “Move!” Boots flood the room. A flashlight beam sweeps, catches the vent mist, and turns it into a glowing sheet. Someone swears. Another voice—higher, controlled—says, “He’s in the walls. Find the panel.”

Inside the chase, it’s warmer, tighter. Dust and hot wiring smell like an old radio. The ladder vibrates faintly under Vell’s weight. Below, Myra hisses up, “There’s a junction down here—two directions. And—Rafe—there’s water sound. Not normal. Like… behind the wall.”

As you descend, you hear it too: a low, patient gurgle somewhere in the chase, out of sync with the building’s plumbing—like tidewater in a place it shouldn’t be.

I drop the last rungs fast and press in close to Myra at the junction, voice barely there. “Which way’s drier—airflow, dust, anything? We take that.”  

I grab Vell’s sleeve and pull him tight to the wall. “If you breathe loud, you die. Nod.”  

Then I tilt my head, listening hard—one ear to the metal for footsteps above, the other tracking that wrong gurgle—before I lead them down the drier branch, knife low, moving in a crouch.
messages.player_reasoning: They’re about to find the loose panel above us, so we need to move fast and quietly. The water sound feels like the old curse breathing down my neck; I’ll avoid it if possible, but I’ll keep it in mind as a threat that might cut off our route.

messages.content:
Myra presses two fingers to the left branch’s edge, then the right, reading it like weather. “Right,” she breathes. “Dust sits. Air’s moving *out* of it—warmer. Left’s… tacky. Salt on the metal.”

Vell nods hard when you pin him to the wall. He clamps his mouth shut with his own hand, eyes wide, shoulders shaking but quiet.

You listen. Through the ladder’s frame you catch the Authority above—boot soles on concrete, a cabinet door slammed, then a voice right on the other side of your mis-seated panel: “Here—this panel’s bowed.” Metal scrapes as someone gets fingers under it.

The wrong gurgle comes stronger from the left branch—closer than it should be—like water breathing through a narrow throat. And under it, a faint *clink*… *clink*… like a buoy bell being tapped out of time.

You take the drier right branch, crouched, knife low. The passage tightens; cable bundles brush your shoulder, leaving black grit on your sleeve. The air is warmer here, faintly ozone-stung, and you feel a draft against your cheek—an exit somewhere ahead.

Behind you, the service panel above finally screeches as it’s peeled wider. Light knifes into the chase and a flashlight beam stabs down the ladder well. Someone calls, “They went down—junction!” Another voice—Inspector Rook’s, tight and furious—answers from the room: “Don’t follow blind. Cut them off at the corridor. Now.”

Myra grabs your sleeve and points ahead without speaking: a narrow grille at knee height, painted over too many times, its screws newer than the rest—fresh work. Past it, you can hear a muffled hum of fluorescents and the distant echo of footsteps in a larger hallway.

From the left branch, the gurgle surges once, answering your movement like it noticed. The salt taste floods your mouth—sharp, immediate.

I put two fingers to Myra’s lips—quiet—then crouch at the painted grille and test it with the knife tip, gentle, feeling for a tripwire or tension. “Vell, hold Myra’s belt and don’t move,” I whisper, then start backing the screws out just enough to peek through before committing.

messages.content:
You hush Myra with two fingers; she freezes, eyes on your hand, then gives the smallest nod. Vell obeys too—one hand clamps Myra’s belt, the other braces on the chase wall to keep from swaying. He’s shaking, but silent.

You probe the painted grille with your knife tip first. The paint flakes in brittle curls. No give from a wire, no spring tension—just old metal and newer screws. You slide the blade under the edge and feel along the seam: no adhesive, no razor strip. Whoever replaced the screws didn’t bother with a trap—just speed and concealment.

You start backing the top-left screw out a few turns, slow enough to keep it from squealing. The screw is fresh, threads clean; it comes easy. Second screw—same. The grille loosens a hair, enough for a thin line of air to breathe through.

You tilt it outward a fraction and peek.

Beyond is a service corridor with fluorescent hum and pale tile—Harbor Authority beige. A Compliance placard hangs crooked on a door across the hall. More important: two sets of boots are visible at the far end—Authority officers moving past left to right, flashlights down, not looking into the lower wall space. Their radio murmurs: “Rook wants the corridor sealed. Check vents, chases, ceilings.”

Myra leans close without touching you and whispers into your ear, barely sound: “That’s the service corridor to FILES. If they seal it, we’re boxed.” She swallows. “And—Rafe—the intake sound… it’s *following* the walls.”

Right on cue, the wrong gurgle you left behind swells, closer than it should be, and the faint off-beat *clink* answers—like a buoy bell tapped from inside the building. The metal around the chase seems to sweat cold for a moment. Somewhere above the ladder well, a panel bangs—someone still tearing the chase open.

I wait for the boots to pass, then ease the grille wider and hiss, “Now—one at a time, low and fast.” I shove the grille open just enough, slide out first to check both directions, then pull Myra through by the wrist and Vell by the collar, keeping us tight to the wall under the fluorescents. “We don’t run,” I whisper, “we *belong*—heads down, walk like we’re late.”
messages.player_reasoning: The patrol’s about to seal the corridor and the water-thing is closing in; I’d rather risk a quick, quiet slip into the hall than get trapped in the walls. We need distance and a new route fast, with Myra guarded and Vell controlled.

messages.content:
The boots at the far end fade past the intersection, their flashlight beams sliding off the tile and away. You widen the grille just enough and slip out first—low, fast, clean—then flatten to the wall under the fluorescents.

Clear left: the corridor runs toward the FILES/Compliance door you clocked earlier, with a “RECORDS / COMPLIANCE” placard and a cheap camera dome in the corner blinking red.

Clear right: the hall bends toward an access stairwell; you catch a smear of moving light there—another patrol sweeping, not yet on you.

You pull Myra through by the wrist. She stumbles once on the lip of the grille, catches herself, and immediately tucks in tight at your shoulder, eyes down like she belongs here. Vell comes next—collar-grabbed, hauled out—his shoes scuff loud on tile. He flinches, but you feel him force the sound down, posture shrinking into “late employee” instead of “fugitive.”

Behind you, from inside the wall, that wrong gurgle surges—close enough to make the grille vibrate in your hand. For a heartbeat the corridor’s air tastes briny, like the sea trying to exhale through the building. Myra’s whisper is a thread: “Rafe… they’ll seal this floor. Rook said ‘cut off’—they’ve got keys to the stair doors.”

Up ahead, the camera dome’s red blink seems to track nothing—fixed angle—but it’s pointed right where you emerged. And from the bend to the right, a radio crackles nearer: “—corridor sweep in thirty seconds. Confirm vent points.”

You start walking—heads down, pace clipped, like you’re late and annoyed about it. Under the fluorescents your shadows look too sharp, like they don’t quite match your feet.

I keep walking but angle us tight under the camera’s blind spot, murmuring, “Eyes down—act pissed, like you got called in.”  

As we pass beneath it, I tug my jacket collar up and lift my forearm like I’m checking a watch, trying to block the lens for a beat. Then I steer us straight to the “RECORDS / COMPLIANCE” door and try the handle like I’ve got every right to be there. “Myra—do you have a badge, key, anything. Now.”

You slide tight under the camera’s corner—close enough that the lens can’t see much but jacket shoulder and fluorescent glare. The collar-up/forearm “watch check” buys you a beat; the red blink continues, indifferent, but you’ve cut the clearest view of your faces.

You hit the **RECORDS / COMPLIANCE** door like you own it and try the handle.

Locked. Solid commercial latch—no rattle, no mercy.

Myra’s hand is already in her pocket. She produces a thin, scuffed **Harbor Authority badge card** on a retractable clip and a small ring with two keys. “Badge is mine,” she whispers, voice tight. “Keys—records cages and supply, not always the main. Main’s usually a swipe.” She glances at Vell, then back at you. “If the swipe fails, I can get us in if you can give me *ten seconds* and cover the click.”

From the bend to your right, the approaching patrol’s light sweeps the corridor wall—closer now. A radio crackle carries: “Compliance door—check it. Harrow wants those exports seized.”

And from inside the wall behind you, the gurgle shifts—like something wet dragging itself along sheet metal toward the grille you came through. The corridor’s air turns briefly cold and salty, then normal again, as if the building swallowed.

Vell keeps his eyes down, jaw clenched hard enough to tremble. “They see me, I’m done,” he breathes without moving his lips.

Myra raises the badge toward the reader panel beside the handle—waiting on your signal.

messages.content:
Myra swipes.

For half a second nothing happens—then the reader gives a reluctant **green blink** and a soft chirp. The latch clicks open under your impatient hand. You pull the door inward just enough to make it look like routine access, and you slip all three of you through in a tight stack.

Your bored call toward the bend lands: “Compliance—door’s acting up. Give us ten seconds.”

A flashlight beam pauses at the corner. A man’s voice answers, irritated and distracted, like he doesn’t want paperwork tonight: “Make it five. Harrow’s taking copies—Rook wants *everything*.” The beam moves on, not committing to the turn yet.

Inside, the **FILES/Compliance room** is colder than the hall—metal shelving, a workstation with a docked terminal, and a low cabinet line along the back wall. The door shuts behind you with a muted click that sounds too loud in the quiet. Through the small wired-glass window, you see the patrol’s light sweep past without stopping.

Vell bends forward, hands on knees, holding his breath exactly like you told him, eyes pinned to the tile.

Myra doesn’t celebrate. She’s already moving—whispering fast: “If they’re ‘taking copies,’ they’re either pulling the last three nights’ exports or rewriting incident timestamps. If we don’t grab what we need now, it’s gone.” She glances at the back cabinets like she knows which one lies.

Then you notice it: one of the lower drawers along the back line sits *too* flush, like it’s been reseated carefully. The metal around it has faint scrape marks where someone’s pried and then made it pretty again.

In the wall, far behind you, that wrong gurgle dulls—like it’s lost your scent for a moment—then the buoy-bell rhythm taps once, faintly, through the pipes.

Vell, eyes on that window—if light stops, you hiss.”

messages.content:
Your fingers find the scrape marks—and the moment bare skin brushes the cold metal edge, it’s like the drawer bites back.

Cold salt fire races up your arm in a numb, flooding rush. Your hand spasms; the knife tip skitters with a sharp *tink* against the cabinet face. For an instant you taste brine and pennies, and the building’s pipes answer with a faint, wrong **bell-tap**—not from outside, but *through the walls*, like the harbor is counting you from inside the Authority’s bones.

The drawer doesn’t spring; it *gives*—just a hair—like something inside was meant to be found, but only after it knows your name.

Myra snaps her head toward you, seeing your hand go rigid. “Rafe—don’t touch it—” she hisses, then forces herself back to the terminal, hands moving fast anyway. She yanks open a desk side tray, finds a stubby admin camera and a coiled cable. “I can’t ‘pull’ without leaving a trace, but I can *capture* what’s on-screen and whatever’s in that drawer if you can get it open.”

Vell is at the wired-glass window, one eye on the corridor. He doesn’t speak—just raises two fingers: patrol light is still moving, but slower now, like someone’s reconsidering the turn.

Inside the drawer, as you ease it with the knife tip, you see a thin bundle: **carbon forms** with Harbor Authority “accident” headers, pre-stamped and signed in a tight hand—time-of-death fields already filled with times that don’t match the incident numbers. Tucked beneath them: a **tide chart strip** with minute marks and a penciled note: **PIER NINE / INTAKE / “RETURNED”**.

Your arm keeps burning cold. The air in the room thickens, fog-damp without fog—like the ward you tripped is trying to locate you through the building.

If you don’t break line-of-sight with this cabinet and get that hand rinsed and wrapped soon, the “call” is going to get louder.

**SENSORY GROUNDING:** FILES/Compliance back cabinets; metal drawer half-open; wired-glass window shows corridor sweep.

**STATUS UPDATES:** Drawer: partially opened  
**STATUS UPDATES:** Evidence: forms + tide strip  
**STATUS UPDATES:** Patrol: slowing near bend

I grit my teeth and hook the bundle of accident forms and the tide strip out with the knife tip into my jacket, keeping my bare fingers off the metal. “Myra—photo them, quick; no flash,” I mutter, then strip my bandana off and wrap my forearm tight, twisting it like a tourniquet.  

To Vell, low: “If that light stops, you *hiss* and we’re out—door or vent, I don’t care.” I lean close to Myra while she shoots the pics. “Pier Nine intake—‘returned’… you ever hear that phrase before?”
messages.player_reasoning: The ward mark feels like a beacon—if I stay on the cabinet, whatever’s in the walls will find us. We need the evidence fast, get Myra’s photos, then rinse/wrap my arm and prepare to move before the patrol commits.

messages.content:
The knife tip hooks the bundle cleanly. You keep your skin off the metal and slide the **pre-stamped forms** and **tide strip** into your jacket. The moment they leave the drawer, the cold pressure in the room eases a fraction—like you took something a hook was set to hold.

Myra nods once, jaw tight, and raises the little admin camera. No flash—just the faintest shutter ticks as she frames the headers, the incident numbers, the impossible times-of-death, and the penciled **PIER NINE / INTAKE / “RETURNED”**. She angles the camera so the wired-glass window can’t catch the screen reflection.

You strip your bandana and cinch your forearm. The burn doesn’t stop, but it dulls from “screaming cold” to a steady, nauseating throb. Salt stings your nose as you twist the cloth tight; the ward mark under it feels like it’s trying to pulse in time with that wrong bell-tap in the pipes.

Vell stays glued to the window. The corridor light slows—then pauses. He inhales to hiss.

Before he can, a radio squawks outside, close: “—Rook wants Compliance sealed after pull. If the clerk’s in there, drag her out.” Boots stop just past the door; you can see the shadow line through the wired glass, broad-shouldered, lingering.

Myra answers your whisper without looking up from the camera. “Yeah,” she murmurs. “Facilities says ‘returned’ when the **intake screens** catch… things. Driftwood, bodies, whatever the pumps spit back out. But Tideglass uses it like a *term*. Like a name comes back into the ledger.” She swallows. “Pier Nine’s annex has an intake crawl. If they wrote it down to the minute, it’s not maintenance.”

She finishes the last photo and slips the camera into her pocket. “I can’t keep this badge hot forever. If they start checking swipes, they’ll see me.”

**SENSORY GROUNDING:** Back of FILES/Compliance; wired-glass window shows a stopped shadow at the corridor.

**STATUS UPDATES:** Evidence pocketed + photographed  
**STATUS UPDATES:** Forearm wrapped; pain dulled  
**STATUS UPDATES:** Patrol stopped outside door  
**STATUS UPDATES:** “Seal Compliance” order active

I press a finger to Myra’s lips and whisper, “Pocket the badge—now,” then I step to the door and in a bored clerk voice call, “Compliance is empty—terminal’s locked out. You want me to wait for Harrow or go back to my station?”  

I glance around fast for a second exit—vent, service hatch, anything—and murmur to Myra, “Is there a back way out of this room?”
messages.player_reasoning: Boots are right outside and “seal” means we’re about to be trapped; I’d rather gamble on misdirection than a fight. I’ll set up a believable “room’s empty” moment, then slip out the back if there is one, using Myra’s knowledge and keeping Vell from panicking.

messages.content:
Myra freezes at your finger, then exhales through her nose and slides **the Harbor Authority badge card** off her lanyard and into her inside pocket like it’s a live razor. Her eyes flick to the wired-glass window: the shadow outside shifts, listening.

You step to the door and put on that bored, put-upon clerk tone. “Compliance is empty—terminal’s locked out. You want me to wait for Harrow or go back to my station?”

A beat. Then a man answers from the hall—close enough you can hear the wet squeak of his rain gear. “Locked out?” Suspicious, but not certain. “Stand by. We’re sealing the room. Don’t touch anything.”

Another voice, farther back, radio-tinny: “Rook said nobody stands by. Sweep and clear. If it’s empty, prove it.”

The shadow at the window leans in; a flashlight beam tries to angle through the wired glass, turning it into a milky glare. Vell’s shoulders rise—he’s fighting the hiss down, throat tight.

You glance fast: along the **back wall**, behind the cabinets, there’s a narrow **service access panel**—painted the same dull gray as the wall, with two screws showing fresh tool marks. Above it, near the ceiling line, a **return vent grille** sits slightly crooked, one corner darker with damp.

Myra murmurs without moving her lips, eyes on the panel: “Back way—yeah. That panel goes into the service chase behind Compliance. But it’s tight and loud if the screws fight. The vent’s worse—drops into the wrong ducting unless you know the turn.” She swallows. “If they open this door, they’ll see Vell first.”

Outside, the door handle tests once—gentle, like they’re checking if it’s latched—then stops. Someone’s deciding whether to key in or force it.

**SENSORY GROUNDING:** Inside FILES/Compliance; door to corridor east; service panel on back wall; vent near ceiling.

**STATUS UPDATES:** Myra badge: pocketed  
**STATUS UPDATES:** Patrol: flashlight at window  
**STATUS UPDATES:** Door handle: tested once

Without turning my head, I murmur, “Panel. Now. Vell first,” then I plant myself at the door and call out, still bored, “You want me to open it for your sweep or you gonna break it and write me up for it?”  

I slip my knife to Myra hilt-first. “Use this—quiet as you can,” and with my free hand I tug Vell back toward the cabinets, ready to shove him through the moment the panel gives.
messages.player_reasoning: The patrol’s about to come in and Vell will get spotted; the service panel is our quickest hidden exit, even if it’s loud. I’ll buy seconds at the door while Myra works the screws, then shove Vell through first.

messages.content:
Myra takes the knife hilt-first, face gone flat with focus. She drops to a knee behind the cabinets, shoulders hunched to hide the motion, and sets the blade tip into the first screw head.

At the door you keep the bored edge in your voice. “You want me to open it for your sweep or you gonna break it and write me up for it?”

It works—halfway. The voice outside snorts, annoyed. “Open it. Now. Hands where I can see ’em.”

The handle shifts again, firmer this time, like they’ve got a key and are done negotiating.

Behind you, the knife turns with a soft, gritty *skritch*. The screw gives—too loud in the hush—and the service panel shivers. Myra pauses, listens, then keeps going. Second screw fights; she leans her weight into it, careful not to strip it. Vell is right there, breathing through his nose, eyes on the panel opening like it’s oxygen.

Through the wired glass, the flashlight beam cuts off, replaced by a face pressed close—distorted by the mesh. A Harbor Authority officer, young and jumpy, scanning for movement. His radio whispers: “—Harrow’s sweep is personal tonight. Nobody slips.”

You tug Vell back hard; he bumps the cabinet, metal ticking. The officer’s head snaps toward the sound.

Myra finally frees the second screw. The panel edge pops loose just enough to get fingers under—she peels it back a handspan and cold, stale air spills out from the service chase, smelling of dust and brackish damp. It’s tight, but it’s real.

Outside, the key scrapes in the lock.

**SENSORY GROUNDING:** FILES/Compliance door east; service panel opening behind the back cabinets, low and cramped.

The pressure in your wrapped forearm pulses once, like the ward recognizes the “back way,” and somewhere deep in the building a pipe gives a tiny, wrong **bell-tap** in answer.

I throw my voice at the door, sharper now like I’m offended. “You want my hands where you can see ’em? Fine—count to three and I’ll open it. If you key it and snap the latch, I’m not signing the damage report.”

Without looking back, I grab Vell by the collar and shove him down into the service panel opening. “Go. Crawl. Don’t stop.” Then I hiss to Myra, “You’re next—evidence tight,” and keep my body squared to the door, ready to yank the panel closed behind her the second she slips in.
messages.player_reasoning: The door’s about to open, so I need to buy seconds and get Vell into the chase; if anyone gets caught, it can’t be Myra with the evidence. I’ll keep the guard’s attention on me while silently pushing Vell through, then Myra.

messages.content:
“Count to three and I’ll open it,” you snap, offended on purpose. “If you key it and snap the latch, I’m not signing the damage report.”

On the other side of the door there’s a half-second of silence—then the officer bites, irritation overruling caution. “Fine. Three.” The key stops turning. The handle stills.

You don’t look back. You hook Vell by the collar and drive him into the service opening. He goes on hands and knees, shoulders scraping the frame, then disappears into the service chase with a wet inhale and a whisper of fabric on dust. You hear him once: a muffled, “I’m—good,” already crawling.

Myra’s right behind him, tight as a wire. She tucks the camera and papers hard against her ribs, then slides in sideways. The panel edge nicks her sleeve; she doesn’t react. As she vanishes into the dark, she breathes, barely audible: “Pier Nine annex has a pump-yard keybox—if they haven’t changed it.”

The corridor voice starts again, louder, committed: “Two—”

You yank the panel back into place as quietly as you can, but the metal kisses the frame with a soft *tink*. In the same instant, the lock clicks—someone outside can’t help themselves and twists the key anyway.

“—Three.”

The latch releases. The door begins to swing inward.

**SENSORY GROUNDING:** You’re in FILES/Compliance, squared to the east door; behind you, the re-seated service panel sits low behind cabinets, its screws missing, edges not quite flush.

The officer steps in fast with his flashlight up, catching your face and the empty space behind you. His eyes flick to the cabinets—then down to the panel seam, noticing the slight misalignment. “Where’s the clerk?” he demands, and his radio crackles as another set of boots approaches the threshold.

Outside, deeper in the building, that wrong buoy-bell cadence seems to echo in the pipes—like the harbor itself is keeping time with this breach.

**STATUS UPDATES:** Vell: in service chase  
**STATUS UPDATES:** Myra: in service chase  
**STATUS UPDATES:** Door: opened by patrol  
**STATUS UPDATES:** Panel: closed, unscrewed

I lift both hands, palms out, and step forward into his light to crowd the doorway. “Clerk’s on break—bathroom down the hall. You want him, go yell at Facilities; I’m just here because the terminal kicked me out.” I angle my body to hide the cabinet line and jerk my chin at the officer’s radio. “You sealing this room or doing a full sweep? ’Cause if you’re sealing it, you’re already contaminating it standing in my doorway.”
messages.player_reasoning: I need to keep their attention on me and away from the panel seam; the best play is to act like an irritated, low-level employee with nothing to hide, and physically block their line to the cabinets while giving them a plausible “clerk” explanation.

messages.content:
You crowd the doorway with your hands up and your shoulders squared, eating the flashlight beam so it can’t rake the cabinets clean. The officer’s posture shifts—half reflex, half relief—because you’ve given him something procedural to hold onto.

“Clerk’s on break—bathroom down the hall,” you say, and when you needle him about contamination, his jaw tightens. He glances at his own boots on the threshold like you’ve caught him stealing.

Immediate outcome: he doesn’t push past you. He backs a half-step into the corridor and tries to regain authority with rules.

“Don’t get cute,” he says, but his voice wobbles. “We’re… securing. Not your job to talk chain-of-custody.” Then, lower, like he hates himself for saying it: “Harrow wants the logs and the tags. Anything stamped. Anything with Calder on it.”

Your name in his mouth lands heavy; the salt-burned skin under your wrap prickles.

Behind him, another pair of boots arrives—older, heavier. A second officer leans into view, face set, eyes already scanning past you for angles. He notices the slight mis-seat of the cabinet line, not the panel itself—yet. He doesn’t raise a flashlight; he raises a hand like he’s calming a dog.

“Rook’s order was clear,” the older one says to the younger, eyes on you. “We don’t break seals. We don’t make noise. We take what Compliance already exported.” He flicks his gaze to the terminal area. “You. Contractor. Step out. Door stays open.”

In the corridor, the radio on the younger officer’s shoulder hisses with overlapping traffic—Union pickets at Pier Nine, a “memorial crowd,” and an instruction repeated twice: “No civilians in the sweep lanes.”

**Sensory grounding:** You’re at the east doorway of FILES/Compliance, body blocking the sightline; corridor fog-cold air washes in, smelling of wet wool and antiseptic.

**Environmental pressure:** If they enter and start a “proper” sweep, someone will notice the missing screws; if they pull you into the hall, you lose control of the room’s sightlines.

**STATUS UPDATES:** Patrol: hesitates, procedural  
**STATUS UPDATES:** Calder name flagged on radio  
**STATUS UPDATES:** Second officer arrived, assertive

I let my hands lower a fraction like I’m swallowing my pride, and I edge one step into the hall—only enough to satisfy the order—keeping my shoulder and hip braced in the doorway. “Door stays open, sure. But you want what Compliance exported, it’s not in the room—it’s in the queue. You drag your boots in there and you’ll have nothing but dust and a complaint.”  

I tip my chin at the younger officer’s radio. “Harrow wants stamped logs with my name on ’em? Then tell me what case number he’s chasing and I’ll pull the export from the terminal history—right here, in your light—no sweep, no noise.”
messages.player_reasoning: They’re sniffing around my name and that cabinet line; if I step out cleanly, they’ll see the panel and Myra/Vell are dead. I’ll comply just enough to look harmless, then bait them into focusing on the terminal and “exports” while I keep my body between them and the cabinets—maybe even volunteer to fetch the “exported” packet so they don’t sweep.

messages.content:
You give them the inch they demanded—one step into the corridor—without giving up the doorway. Your shoulder stays planted against the jamb like a wedge.

**Immediate outcome:** it lands. The older officer’s eyes flick from your braced hip to the room behind you, weighing the hassle of forcing entry against the neatness of “export history.” He makes a small, decisive motion with two fingers: hold.

The younger officer swallows, touches his radio as if it’s hot. “Case number…” he starts, then hesitates—because saying it out loud feels like admitting there is a case. He glances to the older one for permission.

The older officer answers instead, voice low and clipped: “There isn’t a case number. Not yet. That’s the point.” Then, after a beat: “We’re collecting anything that *creates* a case. Tags, stamps, time-of-death discrepancies. Anything that makes Harrow look like she missed something.”

That tells you two things at once: they’re not here to investigate; they’re here to pre-empt.

He steps closer, stopping just outside arm’s reach, keeping his body between you and the corridor traffic. “You pull export history in our light, you don’t touch the stamp kit, and you don’t close that door. If you try to get clever, I’ll have you cuffed and we’ll open every panel in this wing.”

The younger officer finally blurts what he knows, like he can’t hold it: “They’re calling it a ‘predictive paperwork ring.’ Tags showing up before deaths. Harrow thinks somebody’s forging Authority time.” His gaze darts to your wrapped forearm and then away.

**Sensory grounding:** Corridor fluorescents buzz overhead; cold air from the hall lifts the paper-dust smell out of Compliance.

Behind the older officer, the hall is starting to clog—more boots, a clipboard inspector with shaking hands, and somewhere distant a muffled chant of Union voices bleeding in from the waterfront side. The radio squawks again: “Pier Nine crowd forming. Tideglass candles. Keep sweep lanes clear.”

Time pressure tightens: if they decide you’re stalling, they’ll breach the room; if you comply, you’re at a terminal with their eyes on your hands while Myra and Vell crawl blind behind the wall.

**STATUS UPDATES:** Patrol pauses; conditional compliance  
**STATUS UPDATES:** No case number; pre-emptive grab  
**STATUS UPDATES:** Pier Nine memorial escalating

I nod once, tight-jawed. “Fine. You want it in your light, you get it in your light.”  

I step backward into Compliance slow, palms still open, and angle my body so I’m between their line of sight and the cabinets. “You—” I point at the younger officer’s radio hand, “—keep that light on my hands. You—” to the older one, “—tell Harrow if she wants to make me a problem, she can come do it to my face.”  

Then I move to the terminal deliberately, fingers careful and visible. “Show me what time window you want—last 24, last week, or since the last Pier Nine incident?” I pause, eyes flicking to his. “And who’s calling it ‘predictive’—Harrow, or somebody above her?”
messages.player_reasoning: If I stall, they’ll tear the wall open and catch Myra and Vell. If I comply, I can keep them out of the room and maybe learn what Harrow’s really after—plus buy time for the crawl. I’ll play cooperative, keep my hands visible, and steer them toward a harmless “export history” view while I listen for anything behind the panel.

messages.content:
The older officer lets you back into Compliance without following—exactly as you framed it: your room, their light. The younger one stays in the doorway, flashlight trained on your hands so hard it washes the terminal keys pale.

**Immediate outcome:** you get to the terminal and wake it without being grabbed or pushed off the station. The older officer stays just outside the threshold, watching the cabinet line over your shoulder like he’s trying to see through you.

The terminal’s screen flickers from sleep to a Compliance login banner—then a yellow notice: **TEMP EXPORT QUEUE: LOCKED (SWEEP AUTHORITY)**. Someone already put a leash on it.

“You’re buying yourself time,” the older officer says, not quite accusing, not quite admiring. When you mention Harrow coming to your face, his mouth twitches. “Commissioner doesn’t do face-to-face with contractors. She does signatures.”

You ask for the window and who’s calling it predictive.

The younger officer answers before the older can stop him: “Last seventy-two. Since the fog started. And… it wasn’t Harrow who said ‘predictive.’ That came down from Annex—Compliance Oversight. They’re the ones asking for ‘pre-incident tags.’” He realizes he’s said too much and clamps his jaw shut, knuckles whitening on the radio.

The older officer’s eyes cut to him—warning. Then back to you. “You pull what you can. If it’s locked, you show us the lock. No tricks.”

**Sensory grounding:** You’re at the Compliance terminal on the north wall; behind you, your hip still blocks the cabinet seam, while corridor air breathes in cold and damp through the open door.

In the hall, that clipboard inspector you clocked earlier edges closer, pretending to read but listening—his hands still shaking like he’s reciting someone else’s script. The radio spits Pier Nine again: “Memorial crowd—candles—Union on approach.”

Somewhere behind the wall, a faint *scrape* travels through the service chase—Vell or Myra shifting—and the older officer’s head tilts a fraction, like he heard it too but can’t place it.

**Status updates:** Terminal: export queue locked  
**Status updates:** “Annex Oversight” implicated  
**Status updates:** Patrol: holding doorway open

I tilt the screen slightly so they can see the yellow notice clear. “There. Locked by Sweep Authority—so if you want ‘no tricks,’ you’re looking at the leash.”

I keep my hands visible and click into whatever the terminal will show without credentials—system status, audit banner, access request—then glance back at the older officer. “Who signed the sweep token? Name, not rank. If Annex Oversight is steering this, I want it on record you asked me to pull something I’m not authorized to touch.”

I raise my voice a notch toward the hall, like I’m complaining to the building. “And tell your clipboard friend to stop hovering—if he’s here to witness, he can witness from the doorway.”
messages.player_reasoning: The lock notice gives me a clean, non-suspicious reason to keep them at the threshold while I probe for any visible metadata or audit trails; I also want to needle “Annex Oversight” without spooking them into a full sweep, and cover the scrape behind the wall by redirecting attention to procedure.

messages.content:
You cant the monitor so the yellow **TEMP EXPORT QUEUE: LOCKED (SWEEP AUTHORITY)** warning sits dead-center in their flashlight beam.

**Immediate outcome:** it forces the older officer to acknowledge—out loud—that you’re not stonewalling. He leans in just enough to read it, then straightens, irritation redirected away from you and toward whoever tightened the leash.

“Yeah,” he mutters. “That’s a sweep token.”

You keep your hands clean and visible, clicking only what a locked terminal will give you: a system status pane, an access-denied audit banner, and a “Request Temporary Authorization” screen. The audit banner helpfully lists the last policy push:

**POLICY UPDATE SOURCE: ANNEX / OVERSIGHT**  
**TOKEN: SWP-12**  
**ISSUED BY: K. SEDGE (DIGITAL SIGN)**  
**SCOPE: COMPLIANCE EXPORTS / INCIDENT TAGS / LEDGER IMAGES**  
Most of the rest is hashed strings and timestamps—enough to be evidence, not enough to be a full confession.

The older officer’s face tightens at the name. “Sedge,” he says, like it tastes wrong. “Keep that screen where my guy can see it.”

When you raise your voice at the hovering clipboard inspector, the man flinches as if you slapped him. He takes two quick steps back to the doorway line, trying to look official while his hands keep trembling. “Witnessing,” he says too fast. “Just—documenting compliance.”

The younger officer doesn’t move his flashlight off your hands, but his eyes flick to the audit line and stick on **K. SEDGE**. His radio hisses again—Pier Nine, candles, Union movement—and for a second the fog-cold air in the hall smells sharply of wet wax, like the memorial’s already bleeding into this building.

Behind you, through the wall, there’s another faint *tick-scrape* in the service chase—careful, controlled—like someone repositioning a tool to avoid making noise.

**STATUS UPDATES:** Sweep token signer: K. Sedge  
**STATUS UPDATES:** Annex Oversight confirmed on audit  
**STATUS UPDATES:** Clipboard inspector pushed back

I tap the screen right on “ISSUED BY: K. SEDGE,” then look at the older officer. “So you’re here on Sedge’s leash, not Harrow’s—good to know. You want something you can take upstairs? Photograph this audit line and the token scope, then go ask Oversight why they’re locking exports in the middle of a sweep.”

Without turning my head, I drag my knuckles once along the cabinet edge—soft, deliberate—then keep my hands up on the keyboard. “If you insist on an export, you’ll need a live authorization. You calling Sedge, or you want me to file the request so it’s stamped with your names?”

I glance to the doorway at the clipboard guy. “And you—write down exactly what you saw: access denied, sweep token SWP-12, signer K. Sedge. No ‘contractor interference’ bullshit.”
messages.player_reasoning: Sedge’s name is leverage, and the lock buys me a procedural shield; I need to keep the cops focused on paperwork while I quietly signal Myra/Vell to freeze and find an exit.

messages.content:
Your finger taps **K. SEDGE** and the older officer’s jaw works once, like he’s grinding down whatever he wants to say.

**Immediate outcome:** you successfully pivot the pressure off “export now” and onto “authorization or evidence.” The younger officer lowers his light just enough to free one hand and snaps two quick photos—audit line, then token scope—flash off, practiced. The clipboard inspector, pale and sweating, scribbles exactly what you dictated, eyes never leaving the screen long enough to think.

The older officer doesn’t bite on “Sedge’s leash,” but he doesn’t deny it either. “Don’t get cute, Calder,” he says. “Sedge signs the token. Harrow signs the consequences.” Then, quieter, more honest: “Oversight’s been stepping on toes all week. People disappear into Annex meetings and come back… blank.”

Your knuckles drag along the cabinet edge—soft, deliberate. The metal gives a faint *ting* under your skin, and from behind the wall a perfectly-timed *answering scrape* returns, like someone caught the signal and shifted position.

The older officer’s head snaps toward the cabinet seam. His eyes narrow. “What was that?”

The younger officer’s radio crackles over his own tension: “Pier Nine memorial crowd is at capacity. Union pickets pushing through. Authority units redeploying—need bodies on the piers.” The words “need bodies” land wrong in this building.

The clipboard inspector blurts, trying to be useful: “Access denied, SWP-12, signer K. Sedge—recorded,” and holds up his page like a shield.

The older officer exhales through his nose, weighing the corridor call against whatever he thinks he heard in your room. “File the request,” he decides, as if making it procedural makes it safe. “Stamped with our names. If Oversight wants to rubber-stamp it, they can do it while the whole pier’s on fire.”

He steps half a pace back into the hall, thumb on his own radio now, and you catch the first real crack in his control: he’s scared of calling Sedge directly.

**Sensory grounding:** Compliance’s cold fluorescent hum sits above you; the open doorway to the east breathes fog-damp air and radio noise into the room.

**STATUS UPDATES:** Audit photographed; notes recorded  
**STATUS UPDATES:** Authorization request demanded  
**STATUS UPDATES:** Pier Nine redeploy order escalates

I let my hands hover, palms open. “Old building. Pipes talk. You’re jumpy because Pier Nine’s lighting up.”  

I click into the authorization request and start filling it out slow and visible. “Give me your names and badge numbers for the record—both of you—and your unit. Then take your redeploy and get out of my doorway before you ‘contaminate’ something.”  

Without looking back, I murmur under my breath toward the cabinet seam, “Hold. Don’t breathe,” and keep typing.
messages.player_reasoning: Filing the request buys time and keeps them procedural, but the older officer heard the scrape—if he gets suspicious, he’ll breach. I need to calm him, redirect him to the pier redeploy, and quietly signal Myra/Vell to freeze while I submit the request with their names attached.

messages.content:
**Immediate outcome:** Filing the request works—slow, visible, undeniable. The older officer gives you what you asked for, but he does it like he’s paying a toll.

“Rolan Vex,” he says. “Badge 3-118. Unit: Night Compliance Liaison.” He points his chin at the younger one without looking away from you.  
“Eli Marr,” the younger officer answers, voice tight. “Badge 5-044. Patrol Detachment C.”

The clipboard inspector hesitates, then adds—too quickly—“Tomas Pell. Oversight intake.” Not a badge number. Not quite a lie, but not the whole truth either.

You type their names in, and the terminal accepts them into the request fields. When you hit the “Reason” box, the cursor blinks like a heartbeat. The older officer watches your hands, then the cabinet seam, then the hallway, caught between Pier Nine and whatever’s behind that wall.

**Sensory grounding:** You’re still at the Compliance terminal on the north wall; the open doorway to the east spills corridor fog and radio chatter across the floor.

Your murmur—“Hold. Don’t breathe”—lands perfectly. The faint movement behind the cabinet dies instantly. No scrape, no shift, not even the tiny settling noise of metal cooling. Whoever’s in that chase heard you and obeyed.

Vex’s radio squawks again: Pier Nine, units redeploying, Union pressure building. Vex grimaces. “They want us on the piers. And Sedge wants this room clean.” He looks at Pell. “You got a badge number, intake?”

Pell’s pen freezes mid-stroke. “Annex doesn’t issue—” he starts, then stops as if he’s remembered who’s listening. “I’m assigned. That’s all.”

Vex makes a decision you can see: he steps fully into the hall, tugging Marr with him by the shoulder—clearing your doorway like you demanded, but keeping Pell at the threshold as a “witness” he can blame later. “Request goes up,” Vex says. “No exports until Oversight answers. And Calder—if you’re playing games with hidden people in walls, don’t. Annex will drown you in paperwork before the water does.”

As they peel away, Pell lingers one beat too long, eyes flicking to the cabinet seam like he’s trying to memorize it.

You swivel the monitor toward Pell.

Tomas Pell’s throat bobs. He leans in, eyes darting once to the hall where Vex and Marr are already moving fast toward Pier Nine orders. Then he reads, out loud, exactly what you wrote—voice thin but clear—right up to **“access currently denied.”**

When you step in and crowd him, he backpedals without you touching him. “Fine—confirmed,” he says, and there’s a flicker of anger under the fear. “But you don’t understand what you just routed. Annex doesn’t ‘review’ these. They *take custody* of them.”

Pell edges sideways to clear your doorway, but as he passes he drops his voice—something he can plausibly claim you “overheard,” not that he told you. “Sedge is a signature. Not a person. Whoever has the stamp is moving tags through Compliance before the bodies surface. If Pier Nine’s full of candles, they’ll want a crowd to hide the intake.”

Then he’s gone down the hall, pen scratching as he walks, leaving a faint smear of ink on the doorframe where his clipboard grazed it.

In the quiet he leaves behind, your phone vibrates again—blocked number—once, then stops.

messages.content:
The blocked call picks up on the second ring—no greeting, just wet breathing and a buoy-bell *clang* faint in the background, slightly off-beat.

“Calder,” a woman says, voice filtered like she’s speaking through cloth. Not Myra. Older than Myra. Controlled. “Stop looking at clocks. That correction wasn’t your system—Annex pushed a port-wide time sync. They’re aligning reports to a tide window.”

You keep it low and sharp; she answers like she’s been waiting for exactly that question. “Because your request hit the queue. Because you wrote names into it. Because you’re in the building that feeds Pier Nine.”

A pause, then: “Don’t go to the memorial. And don’t trust anyone who says ‘Sedge’ like it’s a person.”

Before you can pin her down, you catch a second voice far away—male, barking—then the woman hisses, “They’re sweeping Compliance next,” and the line goes dead. Your screen immediately shows **NO CALLER ID** like it never happened.

You pivot to the cabinet seam and whisper. For a beat nothing moves—then a slow exhale seeps through the crack, careful as a confession.

“I’m… I’m here,” a man whispers back. Young. Hoarse. “Don’t—don’t open it. They’ll hear.” He swallows, and you hear the tiny click of teeth. “I’m not hurt bad. Just—cold. My name’s Corin. Annex runner. They sent me to pull your request before it routed, and I couldn’t. So I hid.”

**Sensory grounding:** You’re still in the Compliance room, terminal glow on your hands; the east doorway is open to the fog-wet corridor, and somewhere deeper in the building a service cart wheel squeals once, then stops.

Corin’s voice tightens. “They’ve got a stamp kit down there that can backdate anything. Bodies, tags, times. If you stay in this room when the sweep hits, they’ll make you the witness and the culprit.”

From the corridor, distant boots pick up—more than two sets—moving with purpose, radios murmuring. Not Vex and Marr’s hurried retreat; this is a different cadence, slower, coordinated.

**Sensory grounding:** From your crack of hallway, you see fog-beaded fluorescent light and hear rubber soles on wet concrete—steady, coordinated—coming from the south.

Two figures slide into view, not running: Harbor Authority sweep team, dark rain gear, radios low. One carries a flat black case the size of your tool case; the other has a clipboard with a red corner sticker—Oversight marking. Their voices are muted, professional.

“…SWP-12 queue just routed,” the clipboard one murmurs. “Sedge wants Compliance cleared before Pier Nine crowd hits peak.”

The one with the case stops outside your door and listens—head angled, like he’s trained to hear breathing. He tries your handle once, gently, as if checking whether you’re cooperative.

Inside the wall, Corin goes perfectly still. You can feel the tension in the silence he leaves behind.

From deeper in the corridor, another radio crackles: “Pier Nine memorial commencing. Union pickets on approach.” The sweep team doesn’t speed up; they tighten formation.

Corin’s whisper barely makes it through the seam, more urgent now: “If you’re getting me out, it’s the right branch—painted grille. But it’s loud if you pry it. And—Calder—Annex has ears in the chase. Not just me.”

The handle turns again, a fraction firmer, and the door shifts against your nearly-closed position—someone testing whether it’s blocked from inside.

Without looking back, I breathe toward the cabinet seam, barely moving my lips: “Right branch. Now. Quiet.”

Then, to the sweep team, I keep my tone flat and tired. “You want to inventory the room, do it from the threshold. No rummaging—anything you touch becomes chain-of-custody, and I’m not wearing your mess.”

The clipboard officer—rain hood up, red-corner sticker glaring—narrows his eyes. “Ten minutes ago?” he repeats, like he’s tasting the lie for grit. “Annex clock says four.” He tilts the clipboard so you can’t see what’s written. “SWP-12 is live. Oversight wants *everything* that touched the last three nights. That includes contractors who think chain-of-custody is a shield.”

The one with the black case shifts his stance to the side—subtle, trained—trying to get an angle past your shoulder into the room. He doesn’t step in, but his gaze hunts: desk, terminal glow, cabinet line.

Behind you, you breathe toward the cabinet seam: *Right branch. Now. Quiet.* There’s the softest scrape—fabric on metal—as Corin starts moving inside the wall. No cough. No stumble.

The clipboard officer’s radio murmurs, and a third voice answers close by—another sweep member out of frame: “Pier Nine crowd at peak. Union contact says ‘Calder’ is in play.” The clipboard officer’s eyes flick to your throat, then to your hands.

The case-carrier finally speaks, low: “Open it wider. We’re not here for your pride. We’re here for the stamp kit and any blank tags.”

That’s the tell: they already suspect what’s in this room, and they’re checking whether you’ll flinch.

I let out a slow, irritated breath and hold their eyes. “Stamp kit? Blank tags? Wrong room. This is Compliance exports—terminal, logs, and a mop bucket if you’re lucky.”  

I lift my hands where they can see them and jerk my chin at the red-sticker clipboard. “Show me the sweep order with my name on it, and the authorizing signature—right here, in the hall. Until then, you’re not crossing my threshold.”

The clipboard officer’s jaw tightens. He doesn’t show you the paper; instead he taps the red-corner sticker with a gloved finger like it *is* the signature. “Oversight authorization,” he says. “That’s the signature that matters tonight.” But he hesitates, because you’ve made it public, procedural, and loud in a hallway that carries sound.

The case-carrier’s eyes flick past you again, and you see the calculation: force it and it becomes a scene; wait and they might still get what they want with less noise. His radio crackles once—someone asking for status—then he answers, “At Compliance door. Contractor present.”

Behind you, at the cabinet seam, there’s the faintest *shhhk* of fabric and boot rubber—Corin committing to the right branch. It’s steady now, not stop-start. He’s moving like he’s memorized where every bolt head will snag a sleeve.

The clipboard officer leans in a fraction, voice dropping. “You know why we’re really here, Calder? Because someone’s printing time that doesn’t exist.” His eyes cut to the idle terminal glow behind you. “And because Pier Nine is about to ‘return’ something with your name attached.”

Down the corridor, another sweep member edges into view—female, cropped hair under her hood—holding a small evidence satchel already labeled with a blank line for **SUBJECT**. She doesn’t speak. She just watches your hands.

A new sound threads through the building: distant chanting carried by the fog, thin but unmistakable—Pier Nine’s memorial loudspeakers bleeding through the harbor air system. It makes the hallway feel like it’s listening.

Then, from inside the wall: a soft metallic *tick*—not a cough, not a stumble. More like a grille being touched, tested.

The case-carrier shifts closer, trying to crowd you without crossing the threshold. “Last chance,” he says. “Step aside and keep your license.”

**IMMEDIATE OUTCOME:** Your shout flips the hallway from “quiet extraction” to “public incident.” The sweep team freezes for half a beat—long enough for the case-carrier to stop crowding you and key his radio. The clipboard officer’s composure cracks into irritation; he hadn’t wanted witnesses.

Down the corridor, a door opens hard. A voice answers—young, sharp: “This is Vex. Say again?” Footsteps start coming fast, not running but urgent, rubber soles slapping wet concrete.

The clipboard officer leans in, teeth barely showing. “You just made yourself a problem,” he says. Then, louder for anyone listening: “Contractor Calder is refusing compliance with Oversight sweep.” He angles his clipboard like he’s writing your name into a form that already exists.

Behind you—inside the wall—there’s a soft *clink* followed by a faint exhale that isn’t yours. Corin has reached the painted grille and is working it, carefully, trying not to make the pry-squeal. You can hear the metal flex a millimeter at a time.

**SENSORY GROUNDING:** You’re still braced in the FILES/Compliance doorway; to your right the corridor stretches toward the pump house yard, and fluorescent light skitters on puddles like oil.

The woman with the evidence satchel steps closer, stopping just short of your threshold. She finally speaks, voice neutral: “We can do this clean, Calder. Put the tool case on the floor and step back.” Her eyes drop to your key ring, then back up—like she knows Myra’s tag.

Vex’s footsteps get closer. Another voice trails behind him—older, tired, maybe Marr: “Oversight again? Christ.”

The case-carrier’s radio chirps with a new instruction, clipped and impatient: “If contractor obstructs, detain and secure room. No delays. Pier Nine priority.” He meets your eyes and you see the shift—permission granted.

He reaches for your shoulder—not to shove yet, but to claim contact, to make the next move “resisting.”

From the wall, Corin’s grille gives a tiny, decisive *tick*—the kind that means it’s finally loose enough to push.

Without turning my head, I murmur toward the wall seam, barely moving my lips: “Push through. Pump house yard. Don’t look back.”

Your grip and the raised wrist do what you intended: the case-carrier freezes in place, caught between the camera’s stare and your voice carrying down the corridor. His free hand hovers, then drops away from the latches like he’s afraid the tape’s already rolling.

He swallows. “Authority—Compliance courier,” he says too fast. “Badge—” He fumbles at his chest clip with shaking fingers, then thinks better of it and tries to angle his body so the number isn’t clean on camera.

Behind the painted grille seam, there’s the faintest scrape of fabric and shoe rubber on metal—someone committing to the crawl. The vent screws you loosened earlier vibrate once, then settle. The air that slips through smells like wet concrete and pump oil.

Down the corridor, boots answer—two sets, quick. Vex and Marr come into view through the fogged, buzzing docklight spill: Harbor Authority uniforms, rain-sheened caps, hands already near cuffs. They clock your hold, the raised wrist, the camera, and then the case.

Vex slows first, voice hard but careful. “Calder. Let him go.” He looks at the courier. “Dain Rook’s office sent you?” That name lands like a weight; Marr’s eyes flick toward the FILES/Compliance door, then back to you.

The courier blurts, “Inspector Rook said—said it’s a sweep priority. No order needed, it’s internal—” He stops when Marr steps closer and says quietly, “Say your badge number. Out loud. For the record.”

The satchel—black, hard-sided, with a Harbor seal sticker half-peeled—gives a tiny, involuntary twitch as if someone inside the strap line is bracing. Tollen’s knuckles go white around it.

Static. Then a woman’s voice, clipped and practiced. “Marr. Patch to Inspector Rook. Now.” A beat, a breath like paper sliding in a file. “And stop Calder from contaminating Compliance.”

Vex’s gaze hardens at the phrasing—*contaminating*—like he’s heard it used before when someone wanted a person erased from a scene. He glances at Tollen. “Courier doesn’t enter without an order logged,” Vex says, careful but firm, loud enough for the speaker to catch. “You have an incident number?”

Tollen stammers, “It’s internal—he said no—”

The building hum seems louder in the silence that follows, and outside, the buoy bell’s off-beat toll slips through the concrete like a heartbeat that won’t match yours.

messages.content:
The speaker line goes quiet for half a breath—just the hiss of static and the faint click of a relay—like whoever’s on the other end didn’t expect you to demand *their* name on record.

Then the woman answers, voice tightening. “Deputy Commissioner Sable Kint. Harbor Authority Oversight.” She doesn’t sound like Rook’s secretary; she sounds like the person his secretary is afraid of. “This call is not consent to record, Calder. Step away from the Compliance threshold.”

Vex’s jaw works. He looks up at the camera dome, then at Marr, then back to you. Your wording lands: *order number* and *log it*. Vex doesn’t grab you. Instead he shifts his stance so he’s between you and Tollen, palm out toward the courier like a stop sign.

“Copy,” Vex says, loud enough for the speaker and the camera. “Marr—note: unauthorized access request by Eli Tollen, badge three-one-seven-zero. No incident number provided. Calder nonviolent, hands visible.” It’s not the heroic speech, but it’s a paper trail with teeth.

Marr’s eyes flick—quick, nervous—to the phone, then the corridor log terminal mounted under it. He starts keying with two fingers, clumsy in wet gloves. The keys click loud in the narrow hall, mixing with the buzz of the docklight outside the service door to the west.

Tollen’s face goes slick with sweat. “They said—Kint said—” He tries to edge the satchel forward anyway, testing whether Vex will let him pass. Vex plants a boot and blocks him without touching you.

On speaker, Kint’s tone turns flat. “Vex. You are being instructed. If Calder remains, he is interfering with an active safety sweep.” A pause, then: “I can have your badge frozen before morning.”

From behind the painted grille seam deeper in the service chase, there’s another faint rasp—then a soft *thunk*, like someone’s elbow bumping a duct brace as they commit to the pump-yard route. The fog outside presses against the corridor windows, turning the harbor into a blank page—good for cover, bad for witnesses.
