I keep my hands up but angle my body to block their line of sight to her. “You don’t get three nights of my logs on a whisper and a threat—tell Harrow to file a request like everyone else.” I glance back at the woman, low and firm: “Walk. Now. Don’t run—just go,” then I look back to Rook. “You want help? Start by telling me why the toe tag says tomorrow.”

Your body angle works: the uniforms’ lights keep on you and the corpse, not her. The woman takes the cue. She slips sideways along the shadowed edge of a container stack, head down, walking—fast but not running—until the fog swallows her raincoat.

Rook notices a beat too late. His flashlight twitches toward where she went, then snaps back to you, jaw clenched. “Dammit, Calder.” He doesn’t order pursuit—either he can’t spare the manpower, or he doesn’t want a report that says a civilian witness got chased.

The dock under your boots is slick with brine; when the buoy bell hits again it’s still off, like the harbor’s metronome is wrong on purpose. Down-berth, the other sweep team’s lights flare against corrugated doors—padlocks rattling, someone jotting serial numbers.

Rook leans in close enough you catch stale coffee on his breath. “Because it was printed before he died,” he says, voice low. “Tags, forms, timestamps—pre-staged. Harrow calls it ‘administrative efficiency.’” His eyes flick to the toe tag you’re staring at. “And if you’re thinking that’s impossible—welcome to my week.”

One of the uniformed officers, a woman with a clipped ponytail, moves to the body and starts photographing the tag and the face, quick and practiced. The other keeps watch toward the west, where distant voices and the clack of boots on planks are getting louder—Union patrol closing.

Rook’s hand shakes when he points his flashlight at your chest, not quite a threat, more like he needs something to hold onto. “I’m not here to burn you. I’m here because if this goes into the system the wrong way, Harrow buries it and the Union riots over it.” His voice drops further. “You want the real answer? Someone above me is running the paperwork ahead of the water. I don’t know how. I just know Harrow’s orders are to seize every private camera angle before sunrise.”

He glances toward the fog where the woman vanished. “If she talks to Brinehand first, they’ll decide you’re the saboteur. If she talks to Tideglass… she won’t talk again.”

**Status updates:** Witness extracted into fog. Union patrol nearing Berth 12. Rook admits pre-staged tags.

I step in closer so only Rook hears me. “You want cameras? You get one angle, one hour—right now—on my device, and you don’t copy it. You try to seize my logs, I’ll make sure the Union hears you’re scrubbing bodies with tomorrow’s paperwork.”

I flick my eyes toward the approaching boots. “When they hit this pier, you tell your people to stand down and let me talk them off. While they’re yelling, you and I walk—quiet—toward the container stack. You’re going to tell me what Brinehand and Tideglass are, and you’re going to tell me where Harrow keeps the printer that can see the future.”

Rook’s eyes harden at the blackmail, then flick past you to the fog like he’s weighing which fire burns him slower. He gives a tight nod—once. “One angle. One hour. On your device,” he breathes. “No copy.” It’s not trust; it’s triage.

He turns half toward his uniforms and raises his voice just enough to carry. “Hold position. Nobody touches private equipment without my say.” The ponytailed officer pauses mid-photo, annoyed but obedient. The other officer shifts his stance, light trained west where the boots are getting loud.

The air tastes like pennies and salt. To the east, the container stack looms like a dark wall, the fog snagging on its corners and sliding down in sheets. The buoy bell hits again—late.

Union voices swell: rough laughter, a shouted name, the scrape of hook-knives on belt rivets. Rook leans close as you start drifting—casual, unhurried—toward the containers.

“Brinehand’s the union’s teeth,” he murmurs. “They keep the docks ‘safe’ for a price. They also… pay the water. Names go missing when the tide’s wrong.” His throat works. “Tideglass is worse. Charity front. Ledgers, bloodlines, tide charts. They don’t muscle you—they *schedule* you.”

A shout breaks closer: “Authority! Hands off our men!” One of the uniforms starts to answer, but Rook snaps, “Stand down,” like he’s swallowing a lifetime of training.

You and Rook reach the container stack’s shadow. The temperature drops a degree. His voice goes even lower. “Printer that sees the future?” He shakes his head. “Harrow doesn’t keep it in her office. Paperwork comes out of the Harbor Records annex—old building behind **Ing Boots**. Basement. Restricted after the flood. That’s where the tags get ‘processed’ before they ever hit a toe.”

As you edge along the containers, a faint gritty crunch underfoot—salt embedded where it shouldn’t be—clings to the sole of your boot like it’s trying to *remember* you crossed here.

**Status updates:** Rook accepts one-hour view. Union patrol at pier mouth. Harrow link: Records annex basement.

I peel away from the container shadow and head toward the Union voices with my palms open. “Hey—easy. Nobody’s putting hands on anybody. There’s a body in the water and Authority’s already twitchy; you want answers, not an excuse to crack skulls.”  

Then I glance back at Rook. “You keep your people leashed like you promised. After I cool them off, you and I watch that one hour—right here—then I’m going to the annex behind Ing Boots. If you’re lying, Rook, I’ll say your name out loud where it carries.”

I step into the docklight with my palms open toward the Union voices. “Oi—hold up. Nobody swings tonight. There’s a body in the water and if you give Authority a riot, they’ll bury the facts with it.” I hook a thumb back at Rook without looking away from the approaching boots. “Inspector promised his people stay leashed; you want answers, you let me talk—then we all walk away with our teeth still in our mouths.”

You step into the stuttering pool of docklight, palms up. The fog makes your hands look farther away than they are—like you’re offering them to the pier.

The approaching boots slow. Two Brinehand “Night Hands” in oilskins resolve out of the haze by the bait-warehouse shutters, exactly where the darkness is thickest. One has a short gaff hook tucked along his forearm like it’s just another tool; the other keeps his hand near his coat where something metal prints against the fabric. They don’t rush you—your tone and the mention of “riot” lands—but they also don’t stop moving. They angle to bracket you, eyes flicking past your shoulders to Rook and the Authority lights.

“Inspector promised,” the gaff-hand repeats, voice rough with dock smoke. “Inspectors promise a lot.” He tips his chin toward the body. “That one ours. Picket. And we heard he was talking to a *Calder*.”

Behind you, Rook holds his line. He barks, “No contact. No seizures. Stand down,” and for once his uniforms actually do—flashlights dip, batons stay holstered. The ponytailed officer mutters something under her breath but steps back from the corpse.

The second Night Hand sniffs, like he can smell the ink. “Tag’s fresh,” he says. “Accident label already on him—means Authority’s doing favors for somebody. You telling me who’s paying the water now, Calder? Or you want us asking your friends on every pier?”

A gust pushes the fog sideways; for a heartbeat you can see the corrugated bait-warehouse slit they’d been watching from, rust scraped clean to a bright line. The buoy bell rings again—still off, still wrong—and the Union men glance at the sound like they’ve been trained to hear it as a warning.

Time pressure tightens: if Brinehand decides you’re stalling, they’ll take you or take Rook; if Authority panics, they’ll “secure” the scene and disappear the body. In the middle, the corpse’s toe tag flutters, ink tacky enough to catch dock grit.

**Status updates:** Brinehand Night Hands engaged. Authority holding (for now). Scene on a knife-edge.

I keep my hands up and my voice low, steady. “Nobody’s paying the water—someone’s paying *paper* to make it look clean. That tag’s dated tomorrow; if you’ve got men dying on schedule, you’re already on the menu.”

I nod toward the body, then angle my chin toward the Authority lights without challenging them. “Rook’s got his people leashed and I’m keeping it that way. You want answers, give me one hour to show you what my camera saw—then you send one pair of eyes with me to Harbor Records behind Ing Boots. Quiet. No mob, no batons, no excuses.”

I look the gaff-hand straight on. “You said he was talking to a Calder—was it me, or my family name? And what did he say before he went in the drink?”

The word **“tomorrow”** hits them like a thrown nail.

The gaff-hand’s posture changes first—shoulders easing a fraction, hook-hand lowering from “ready” to “present.” The other Night Hand stops trying to slide around your flank and instead plants his boots square, eyes narrowing as he looks at the toe tag like it might bite. You don’t win trust, but you win a pause; the brine in the air feels less like a brawl and more like a negotiation.

“Paper don’t float,” the gaff-hand mutters, then glances past you toward the Authority lights. “But it does *sink* a man.”

Behind you, Rook keeps his people still. One uniform’s radio crackles; Rook covers the mic with his palm and hisses something you can’t catch. Out on the fog line, a low engine note idles—steady, patient—like a skiff holding position without wanting to be seen.

The gaff-hand answers your question without blinking. “Family name,” he says. “Not you personally. He said Tideglass has a ledger that don’t just list donations. Lists **debts**. Lists **blood**.” He jerks his chin at the corpse. “He said Pier Nine’s memorial ain’t a memorial. It’s a window. He said your name shows up when the tide chart hits a certain minute.”

The second Night Hand finally speaks, voice flat. “Last thing he said to me was: ‘If I go under, check the inside of my boot.’ Then he laughed—like he already knew what time he was supposed to die.”

The gaff-hand looks you over again, weighing the hour you asked for. “One pair of eyes, quiet,” he repeats. “Fine. But if your footage is smoke, Calder, we don’t come back asking.”

He gestures with two fingers; the second Night Hand steps toward the body—not to touch it, but to stare at the boots, intent and hungry for that detail.

**Status updates:** Brinehand backs off (conditional).  
**Status updates:** Pier Nine + Tideglass ledger confirmed.  
**Status updates:** “Inside his boot” lead surfaced.

I hold up a finger to the Night Hand edging toward the boots. “Not your hands. Not theirs either. We do it clean—Rook, you pull the boot, I watch, your camera girl documents, and your people don’t start bagging anything until I say.”  

I cut my eyes to the fog line, listening to that idling engine. “And one of you—quiet—tell me who’s sitting out there in a skiff pretending they’re not.”  

Then back to the gaff-hand, steady. “You get your one pair of eyes on me for the annex, but first we see what he hid in his boot. If my family’s in a Tideglass ledger, I want to know what kind of ink they used.”

I keep my palms visible and point a finger at the body’s boots. “Nobody touches him bare-handed—Union or Authority. Rook, you do the pull with gloves while your camera officer documents, and nobody bags a damn thing until I’ve seen it.”  

I tilt my head toward the fog line, listening to that idling motor. “And one of you Night Hands—quiet—tell me who’s out there in the skiff pretending they aren’t.”

Rook hesitates at your “until I say,” jaw working—then he makes a tight, angry decision and turns it into procedure. “Gloves. Evidence line. Now,” he snaps, like it was his idea. The ponytailed officer—camera girl—pulls a small body-cam unit from her vest and taps it on; the red record light winks through the fog.

You’re still at Berth 12, right at the edge where docklight dies into black water. The corpse lies half in a puddle of brine-slick runoff; the toe tag flutters against the boot leather, ink shining wet.

Rook kneels, latex gloves snapping on. He grips the dead man’s ankle and works the boot carefully, twisting to break suction. Leather squeals. The Night Hand you checked stops short, teeth grinding, but he listens.

The boot finally slides free with a soft, ugly *schlop*. Rook tips it upside down over a clean evidence bag the camera officer holds open.

A rolled strip of waxed paper drops out—tight as a cigarette—followed by a small, flat brass token stamped with a buoy-bell symbol. The paper’s edge is stained with salt and something like old ink.

At your mention of the skiff, the second Night Hand answers without looking at you. “Not ours,” he murmurs. “That’s Tideglass. They sit off like that when they’re counting minutes.” He flicks his eyes toward the fog line. “Single outboard, muffled. One person. Raincoat.”

As if on cue, the idling motor note shifts—just a hair higher—then eases back, like whoever’s out there heard their name spoken and is deciding whether to drift closer or vanish.

Behind you, one Authority radio chirps again. Rook clamps it shut with his palm, but you catch a phrase: “…Night Compliance… van on—” then static.

**Status updates:** Boot contents recovered (paper + token)  
**Status updates:** Skiff ID: Tideglass watcher  
**Status updates:** Authority comms tightening up

I lean in close to the evidence bag. “Don’t unroll it in the open—wind’ll steal it. Camera on tight, then we read it with our bodies blocking.”  

I glance at Rook, voice like a blade. “You heard ‘Night Compliance van.’ If that shows, you stall them—jurisdictional pissing match, whatever you’re good at.”  

Then I nod at the Night Hands. “One of you keep eyes on that fog-line skiff and tell me if it moves. If Tideglass is counting minutes, I want to hear the number change.”

Rook gives you a hard look—like he hates taking cues from a contractor—then nods once. “Fine. Tight read. No theatrics.”

The camera officer steps in close, shoulders hunched to make a human wall. You, Rook, and her form a tight wedge over the evidence bag; fog beads on your lashes, and the docklight behind you turns the bag’s plastic into a milky glare until she angles it to kill the reflection.

Rook pinches the waxed paper with gloved fingers and eases it open inside the bag. The paper crackles softly, the sound too loud in the hush.

Inside: a smear of blue-black ink, written fast but deliberate.

> **PIER NINE — LOW TIDE WINDOW**  
> **23:48** (bell count starts)  
> **CALDER MARK CONFIRMED**  
> **“RETURNED” FILED BEFORE WATER**  
> **BRING TOKEN TO ANNEX DOOR / NO LIGHTS**

Under that, a line of numbers—short, like a code—then a name that makes your tongue taste like pennies:

> **RAFE**

Rook’s eyes flick to you, then away, like he’s seen enough to know this isn’t just port paperwork anymore. “Night Compliance van’s Harrow’s people,” he mutters, low. “Not my unit. If they show, I can stall—five minutes, maybe ten—before they start asking why I’m standing over a body with Union this close.”

Off to your right, the gaff-hand Night Hand shifts his stance and raises a battered pair of dock binoculars. “I got the fog line,” he says. “If that skiff breathes, you’ll hear it.”

Out on the water, the idling motor note dips—then cuts for half a second—then returns, quieter. The skiff isn’t leaving. It’s adjusting position to keep you in view without giving you a clean bearing.

Somewhere deeper in the fog, tires hiss on wet asphalt—slow, heavy—coming toward Berth 12 like they already know where to stop.

**Status updates:** Note names Pier Nine 23:48  
**Status updates:** Tideglass wants annex token  
**Status updates:** Harrow van inbound (near)**

```json
{"inventory_add":["Brass buoy-bell token","Waxed note (evidence bag)"],"inventory_remove":[],"abilities_add":[],"locations_add":["Pier Nine","Annex door (unknown location)"],"npcs_add":[]}
```

I swallow hard and keep my voice level. “Rook—bag the note as evidence and keep it. The token comes with me. If Harrow asks, you never saw it.”  

I turn to the gaff-hand. “You want answers? You’re my one pair of eyes. You’re coming with me—quiet—to this annex door. Tell your people to stand down and watch that skiff.”  

Then I lean toward the camera officer. “What’s that short number line—can you zoom and read it clean for me before the van rolls in?”

Rook’s nostrils flare, but he moves fast—like he’s decided speed is the only kind of control left. He seals the waxed note in the evidence bag, slaps a Harbor seal across it, and tucks it into his coat. “I never saw a token,” he says flatly, not looking at you when he says it. The lie lands clean.

You pocket the brass buoy-bell token; it’s colder than the air and leaves a faint metallic-salt smell on your fingers.

The gaff-hand Night Hand—broad shoulders, knuckles split old and new—hesitates when you tell him to come. Then he gives a short nod. “Name’s Jory,” he mutters. “I’m not your friend, Calder. But I want the truth more than I want Union stories.” He cups his hands and calls low to the other Night Hands without turning his head: “Stand down. Eyes on the fog line. No hero shit.” The others melt back toward the pilings, one keeping the binoculars trained on the skiff’s last whisper of engine noise.

The camera officer leans in, thumb working her device. “Hold,” she says, voice tight. She zooms into the bag, fights the glare, then angles her body to block the docklight. In the screen’s cold glow, the short number line resolves:

**09 — 12 — 03 — 48**  
…and beneath it, smaller: **“BELL / WRONG”**

Her eyes flick up to you. “Could be a time split. Or berth numbers. Or… a sequence.”

Down the access road behind the stacked containers, tires hiss again—closer now. A van’s headlights smear through the fog, low and wide, and you catch the silhouette of a roof bar without the courtesy of sirens.

Rook straightens, already putting on his “jurisdiction” face. “Go,” he murmurs at you, almost inaudible. “Before they pin you to this scene.”

**Status updates:** Token concealed on Rafe  
**Status updates:** Note sealed with Rook  
**Status updates:** Jory joins (quiet)  
**Status updates:** Night Compliance van arriving

I grip Jory’s sleeve and pull him into the shadow between containers. “Pier Nine, 23:48—low tide window. We move now, quiet.”  

As we go, I murmur, “09-12-03-48… could be berth markers; keep your ears for bell counts—if they ring wrong, we turn.”  

I shoot Rook a last look over my shoulder. “Ten minutes. Then you don’t know me.”

You yank Jory into the container-shadow and he moves with you, low and fast—no argument, just a grim set to his jaw. The Night Compliance van’s headlights sweep the berth behind you; you hear a door thunk and clipped voices, but the fog and steel stacks swallow you before anyone gets a clean look.

Between containers the air changes—hotter, sour with old citrus rot and diesel. Condensation drips off corrugated walls in slow ticks. Your footfalls go dull on gritty concrete, and the buoy bell out in the harbor keeps that *almost-right* rhythm, like a song you know with one note bent.

Behind you, Rook steps into the wash of the van’s lights and starts talking loud—official, annoyed. “This is an active recovery scene under my seal—identify your supervisor—” The reply is sharper, female, and close enough to carry: “Commissioner Harrow’s sweep. Hand over all footage and any evidence collected tonight.” Rook doesn’t yield, but you can hear the clock in how he talks: buying minutes with rules.

Jory leans in as you move. “Pier Nine’s a straight shot if we cut through the reefer lane and hop the service catwalk,” he murmurs. “But ‘Annex door’—that’s not on the public maps. Authority’s got an annex by the old pump house, west end of Pier Nine. Steel door. No signage. They use it when they don’t want a log.”

At the mention of the number line, he nods once. “09-12-03-48… Berth Twelve’s obvious. Nine could be Pier Nine. Three’s… the third ladderwell on the catwalk, maybe. Forty-eight—could be a locker, or a light pole ID.” He pauses, listening.

The buoy bell rings again—then a fraction early, like it’s skipping ahead. Jory’s eyes sharpen. “That’s what you meant by ‘wrong.’ Someone’s messing with the count. Tideglass does that—sets a rhythm so their people know they’re on-time.”

Far off to your right, out past the stacks, an outboard motor coughs once—fog-line skiff repositioning—and then goes quiet again.

**Status updates:** Slipped van line-of-sight  
**Status updates:** Rook stalling Harrow sweep  
**Status updates:** Jory IDs “annex” near Pier Nine pump house  
**Status updates:** Buoy bell count drifting

I keep moving, shoulders tight to the containers. “Third ladderwell, light pole forty-eight—sounds like a meet point. If you’re steering me wrong, Jory, I’ll know the second the bell skips again.”

I slow just long enough to listen, counting under my breath with the buoy—then gesture ahead. “Reefer lane, catwalk. You go first at the ladder, quiet and low.”

As we slip forward, I murmur, “That skiff cough was a check-in. If we see anyone near the pump house, we don’t confront—just mark faces and get to that steel door.”

Jory goes first without protest, palms flat on the container seam, then slips into the reefer lane where the air turns sharply colder—fans humming inside stacked refrigerated boxes like a distant swarm. He finds the ladder welded to the catwalk support and tests it with a slow, controlled pull before putting weight on it. No rattle. He climbs low and tight, boots landing on rungs like he’s done it a thousand nights.

You pause beneath the ladder and count the buoy bell under your breath.

…one… two… three—

The next ring comes *half a beat early*. Not a drift this time; a deliberate skip.

Jory freezes on the catwalk above you, head cocked. “That’s a signal,” he whispers down. “Not tide. Not wind. Someone’s pulling the rhythm on purpose.”

When you climb up after him, the catwalk gives you a narrow view west toward Pier Nine: fog lit from below by sodium lamps, turning everything into silhouettes and smears. You catch **Light Pole 48** stenciled in flaking white on a post at the far end of the lane—exactly where the service catwalk angles toward the old pump house annex.

Below, in the fog at ground level, two figures move along the reefer row—slow, not working. Harbor-cut raincoats, hands in pockets. One stops under a camera dome and tilts their head like they’re listening to an earpiece. The other drags something wheeled for a second—then lifts it, carrying it to keep it quiet.

The public floor smells of oiled leather and mildew, but the back wall is newer than it should be, hiding a bricked-over doorway to an old tide tunnel. Salt has crusted in a crescent pattern under the counter as if the floor has been briefly underwater more than once.

watchers.name: Mara Quell (counter clerk)
watchers.description: Acts bored and helpful while clocking hands, shoes, and pockets; she watches for anyone asking about missing dockworkers, unusual boot sizes, or purchases that suggest wading or anchoring. She quietly notes names and the direction they leave, then makes a "stock call" that is really a report.

watchers.name: Inspector Halden Rusk (outside, in an unmarked sedan)
watchers.description: Watches the storefront through fogged glass and a cracked mirror tucked in his visor; he’s looking for Rafe or anyone snooping around Ing Boots after-hours. He tracks who enters, how long they stay, and whether they leave with a box big enough to hide ledgers or wet gear.

hidden_guards.name: Backroom "stockman" with a union hook-knife
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Behind the false back wall in the rear stockroom, sitting on a milk crate beside a pallet of rubber waders; he can step through a narrow service gap when the panel is unlatched.
weaknesses: Keep to the public floor and avoid touching the back wall seams
Offer a plausible work order or delivery manifest to stall him
Bright light to the eyes buys seconds; he hates being seen

hidden_guards.name: Salt-slick ward on the threshold
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: A crescent of salt embedded under the counter and along the baseboard leading to the stockroom; it clings to boots and tracks anyone who crosses toward the hidden doorway.
weaknesses: Step over the crescent without touching it (dry soles, no drag)
Scatter ash or iron filings to disrupt the pattern
Rinse the soles with fresh water before moving deeper to reduce the mark

fail_conditions.name: Pushing into the stockroom without a cover story
fail_conditions.description: Ing Boots is a choke point used for quiet handoffs; anyone moving like they’re hunting for something gets treated like a thief or a witness. The shop’s back area is rigged for quick containment and fast calls to muscle.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The clerk’s tone turns flat as she reaches under the counter, and the bell over the door is quietly jammed so it won’t ring again. A moment later, a heavy step sounds from behind the wall and a blade flashes low, aimed at tendons, not hearts. You’re forced into a tight, ugly choice: back off publicly or get dragged into the back where no one hears you.
escape_conditions: Retreat to the public floor and buy something to reset suspicion
Name a believable dock job and a supervisor the clerk might recognize
Create a distraction (spill, alarm, power flicker) and leave before the backroom opens

fail_conditions.name: Breaking or smearing the salt crescent
fail_conditions.description: The ward isn’t just a warning; it’s a claim-marker. Disturbing it calls attention in a way that travels through damp wood and old masonry like a pulse, inviting both human and not-quite-human response.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The air goes cold and wet, as if the room inhales from the harbor. Salt blooms on your tongue and your boots feel heavier, tugged toward the floor like a tide turning. Outside, the buoy bell seems to strike closer, and someone—somewhere—knows your weight, your pace, and your direction.
escape_conditions: Wash hands and soles with fresh water and soap to dull the mark
Leave the building immediately and change footwear before going to the docks
Ground yourself with iron (coin, nail, hook) held in the fist until the nausea passes

secrets.description: A ledger page is stitched into the lining of a display boot: names, dates, and tide times coded as shoe sizes, with a recurring mark beside "Calder" that matches Tideglass memorial plaques.

Behind a rack of oilskins, a newer plank floor hides an iron ring set into old stone; it lifts to a sealed hatch that smells like brine and pennies, leading toward a forgotten tide tunnel under the block.

Ward The Union Voices With.location_description: Ward The Union Voices With is a narrow dockside meeting hall wedged between container stacks and a shuttered net-mender’s shop. The walls sweat salt; old union posters hide newer Tideglass sigils scratched into the plaster. A low, off-beat buoy bell seems louder here, as if the building is tuned to it, and the floorboards nearest the back door stay damp no matter the weather—brine seeping up like a slow, patient breath.

watchers.name: Marta 'Ledger' Venn
watchers.description: A union clerk with ink-stained fingers who never looks up directly; she listens through the rhythm of boots on boards and the way voices break on certain names. She’s tracking who asks about drownings, who mentions the Calders, and who seems to be counting exits.

watchers.name: Inspector Halden Rusk
watchers.description: Harbor Authority plainclothes posted outside in the fog, pretending to smoke near a power junction box. He watches reflections in puddles and window-glass to read who enters and leaves, and he’s looking for anyone prying into 'accidents' tied to the ward’s back-room ledger.

hidden_guards.name: Brinehand 'Hookman' in the rafters
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: In the dark crossbeams above the back-room door, lying on planks behind a hanging tarp of oilskins, with a gaff hook and a short-barrel flare gun.
weaknesses: Keep hands visible and stay in the main room; don’t approach the back-room door without being invited
Bright light upward (phone/flashlight) forces him to blink and shift, giving away position
Offer union business (work, payment, a name) to de-escalate before he commits

hidden_guards.name: Salt-licked Ward-Sentinel
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: In the water beneath the pier-side window, anchored to a barnacled chain; it rises only as a slick, human-shaped ripple when the ward is threatened.
weaknesses: Do not shed blood in the ward; even a cut lip can call it closer
Dry salt and iron filings scattered at the sill disrupt its grip long enough to retreat
Move away from open water and keep to higher ground; it cannot climb dry boards far from the tide

fail_conditions.name: Pressing the Calder sea-debt in public
fail_conditions.description: The ward is a listening post; saying the wrong thing turns a meeting into a hunt. The Union protects its bargains, and the Authority prefers 'accidents' to stay tidy.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: Conversations stop one by one until the room is all silence and eyes. Someone slips out to fetch muscle, and within minutes exits are quietly watched and your name is paired with a time and a tide. Any further push risks being steered toward the water under the guise of 'walking you out.'
escape_conditions: Back off and reframe as a routine investigation-for-hire without mentioning bloodlines or gods
Offer a trade: a recovered cargo lead or protection job in exchange for information
Leave immediately through the main door before the back-room runner returns

fail_conditions.name: Forcing entry into the back room
fail_conditions.description: The back room holds the ward’s real accounts—names, tides, and payments. The Union treats it like a throat: touch it wrong and the whole body bites.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The Hookman drops without warning, pinning you with the gaff while the flare gun turns the room into harsh, accusing daylight. In the confusion, someone calls Harbor Authority 'for safety,' and the official response arrives ready to classify whatever happens next as an unfortunate accident. If you’re dragged outside, the tide under the pier is already waiting.
escape_conditions: Freeze and negotiate immediately; offer to return any taken item and pay a 'fine'
Create a distraction in the main room (fire alarm, breaker switch) to break line of sight and slip out
Get to a crowded, well-lit public stretch of dock where 'accidents' are harder to stage

secrets.description: Behind a peeling union poster is a Tideglass chalk-mark: a tide chart encoded as a hymn stanza, listing three upcoming drownings by date and moon phase. One name is smudged out, but the initial 'C' remains, pressed hard enough to dent the plaster.

Under the warped floorboard near the back-room threshold is a small, tar-wrapped packet: a Harbor Authority incident tag stamped 'RECOVERED—UNCLAIMED' and a rusted key that smells of kelp. The tag number matches a case that was officially closed as a storm accident—the night Rafe’s father vanished.

Docklight With My Palms.location_description: Docklight With My Palms is a narrow service pier wedged between stacked containers and a shuttered bait warehouse. The docklights here are intentionally miswired to stutter in a repeating pattern that masks movement on the water; the slick on the pilings isn’t just algae but a thin, waxy brine-resin used in Tideglass rites. Under the constant diesel stink, there’s a faint copper-salt note that never fully dissipates—old blood washed thin and made to look like rust runoff.

watchers.name: Deputy Inspector Mara Venn
watchers.description: She watches from a Harbor Authority skiff idling in the fog line, logging who enters the pier and how long they stay. She’s looking for Calder-linked faces and anyone asking about recent 'accidents' before the paperwork can be sealed.

watchers.name: Brother Sable (Tideglass Warden)
watchers.description: He listens more than he looks—stationed as a 'volunteer' checking memorial plaques, he uses a conch-shell earpiece to catch names carried by the wind. He’s hunting for anyone who speaks the sea-god’s titles aloud or mentions breaking the debt, then marks them for later.

hidden_guards.name: Brinehand 'Night Hands' in oilskins
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Two union enforcers tucked behind the corrugated bait-warehouse shutters, watching through a slit where rust has been scraped clean; they have a clear angle down the pier to the stuttering docklight pool.
weaknesses: Approach from the waterline under the pier where their sightline breaks
Use Harbor Authority credentials or inspection language to make them hesitate
Bright, steady light (flare/flash) ruins their night-adapted advantage for a moment

hidden_guards.name: Salt-Slick Mireling
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Clinging under the third piling from the end, just below the tide mark; it surfaces only when it tastes fresh blood or hears the old sea-name spoken.
weaknesses: Do not bleed—bandage cuts, avoid splinters and hooks
Freshwater (bottle or hose) makes it recoil and lose grip
Keep moving on dry boards; it is slow to climb above the tide line

fail_conditions.name: Lean too far over the stuttering light pool
fail_conditions.description: The docklight pattern is timed to induce missteps—depth cues warp in the fog, and the boards nearest the edge are softened by brine-resin. The water here is hungry and quiet, and something below is trained to pull when weight shifts wrong.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: Your footing skates on the slick resin and the edge gives just enough to betray you. Cold black water closes over your head with a soft, practiced tug, and the fog swallows your shout before it becomes sound.
escape_conditions: Hook an elbow on a cleat or chain before going fully under
Cut yourself free of any snagging line with a blade
Get a hand on the ladder-rung bolted under the pier (requires knowing it’s there or frantic searching)

fail_conditions.name: Say the sea-god’s title aloud on the pier
fail_conditions.description: Sound carries oddly in the fog here; certain words are treated like a bell. The Fellowship has conditioned the pier with offerings and brine-resin so that speaking the title draws attention—human and otherwise.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The air tightens as if it’s listening, and the buoy bell slips half a beat out of time. A watcher shifts closer in the fog, and the water under the pilings answers with a soft knock—like a knuckle on a coffin lid.
escape_conditions: Immediately change location to break the sound-map (move into container alleys)
Cover the follow-up conversation with loud mechanical noise (start a generator, slam a container door repeatedly)
Use a mundane explanation loudly ('heritage plaque title') to muddy intent

secrets.description: A Harbor Authority incident ledger page is wedged behind a loose memorial plaque: it lists three 'accidental' drownings with identical tide timestamps and a payout code tied to an old family trust. The Calder name is not written, but the victims’ middle names match known Calder maternal lines.

Under the pier, a rusted ladder rung has been newly replaced with marine-grade steel stamped with the Tideglass crest, forming a concealed handhold route to a small ritual shelf: waxy brine candles, a fishhook charm, and a strip of oilskin with a bloodline chart sketched in dock-ink.

Ward The Fog Line.location_description: Ward The Fog Line is a narrow service strip between stacked containers and the outer pilings where the fog clings like wet cloth. Under the salt-glazed grates, old storm drains empty straight into the black water; someone has been rinsing more than fish blood down here. The docklights stutter in a repeating pattern that matches tide charts, not wiring faults—like the place itself is keeping ritual time.

watchers.name: Inspector Lysa Marr (Harbor Authority Night Compliance)
watchers.description: She watches from a parked incident van with blackout curtains, tracking who enters the Fog Line and which names get spoken on the radio. She’s looking for anyone asking about ‘accidents’ tied to the Calder line and for signs a drowning is about to be reclassified.

watchers.name: Brother Senn of Tideglass (Buoy-Keeper)
watchers.description: He drifts through the fog in oilskins, pretending to check a buoy bell line while listening for confessions and bargaining language. He’s looking for bloodline talk, debt talk, and anyone trying to interrupt tonight’s timing.

hidden_guards.name: Brinehand ‘hook-walkers’ on catwalks (2 longshore enforcers)
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: On the second-level container catwalk above the Fog Line, behind a dangling curtain of netting and tarps; they have sightlines to the service lane and the nearest ladder down to the water.
weaknesses: Stay off the open lane; move under the catwalk shadows and keep to the container seams
Offer a plausible work order or Harbor Authority clearance number (realistic paperwork buys time)
Loud mechanical noise (dropping a pallet chain, slamming a container latch) masks footsteps and radio chatter

hidden_guards.name: Saltwrit Barnacle-Thing (anchored ward-creature)
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Clinging to the underside of the lowest pier beam where the storm drain outflow meets the tide; it’s invisible until water is disturbed or a light hits the wet growth at the right angle.
weaknesses: Do not break the waterline; keep boots dry and avoid splashing near the outflow
Bright steady light held on it forces it to retreat into the growth for a few seconds
Copper or iron filings thrown into the outflow foul its grip and make it sluggish

fail_conditions.name: Pushing into the storm-drain outflow to search for evidence
fail_conditions.description: The outflow is part of a Tideglass ward that ‘pulls’ anything living toward the water when the tide turns. In the Fog Line, the current is deceptively strong and the slick grates make footing unreliable.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The water grabs like a hand around the ankle, yanking hard enough to slam knees into the grate. Salt floods the mouth and nose with a cold, metallic bite, and something rough—barnacle or bone—scrapes skin as it drags. The fog swallows any shout, turning it into a distant echo that sounds like a buoy bell.
escape_conditions: Cut free anything snagged and crawl to the ladder rung bolted into the pier beam
Use a rope, chain, or hook to anchor to a piling before approaching the outflow
Shine a steady light into the water to force the ward-creature to loosen for a moment

fail_conditions.name: Confronting the wrong authority figure about ‘ritual drownings’ in public
fail_conditions.description: The Harbor Authority has a practiced system for turning questions into paperwork, then turning paperwork into leverage. In this ward, radios are always on and names travel faster than footsteps.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: A polite conversation becomes an ‘incident interview’ with your words logged and time-stamped. Within minutes, dock access gates in the area start failing closed, and a patrol car rolls through slow with lights off. By the next tide cycle, someone you trust gets a quiet visit and a warning wrapped in official language.
escape_conditions: Keep it framed as a safety concern or insurance discrepancy, not a cult or ritual
Use intermediaries (Union foreman, contractor channel) instead of direct accusations
Leave the ward before your name is fully confirmed and cross to a different dock sector

secrets.description: Behind a rusted ‘NO ACCESS’ placard on the third container from the waterline is a Tideglass tide-slate: a chalky glass tablet etched with names and dates. One name is partially scraped away—‘Cal…’—and the next scheduled mark aligns with the buoy bell’s off-beat timing.

Under the slick grate near the storm-drain, a small bundle is wired to the frame: a waterlogged wallet, a Harbor Authority incident tag, and a strip of copper stamped with the Calder family knot-mark. The tag number matches a ‘missing during storm’ case that was never officially opened.

Cold Metal For A.location_description: Cold Metal For A is a dead-end service catwalk bolted to the back of a refrigerated container stack labeled in flaking stencil: COLD METAL / FOR A. The catwalk sweats brine; every step rings like a confession. A maintenance hatch here hides a Tideglass tide-table cache and a salt-caked drain that feeds straight into the harbor, making the air taste faintly coppery when the water pulls.

watchers.name: Inspector Lysa Vane (Harbor Authority night audit)
watchers.description: She watches from a parked incident van with the lights off, using a long-lens camera through fog-streaked glass. She’s looking for anyone photographing containers, checking seals, or asking after the Calder name—anything that could turn an ‘accident’ into a case.

watchers.name: Brother Silt (Tideglass dockside volunteer)
watchers.description: He drifts the perimeter as a ‘buoy-maintenance volunteer,’ counting footsteps by sound and timing breaths between the docklight buzz. He’s listening for names, debts, and any mention of tide tables or bloodlines, ready to mark the speaker for later.

hidden_guards.name: Brinehand ‘quiet crew’ enforcer behind the reefer stack
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Crouched in the narrow lane between the refrigerated units and the corrugated shutter, masked by compressor noise and fog; he has line-of-sight to the catwalk ladder.
weaknesses: Approach from the waterline side where the compressors drown footfalls
Keep hands visible and talk like a contractor on a job ticket
Bright light to the eyes breaks his aim in the fog

hidden_guards.name: Salt-Woken chainling in the drain mouth
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Coiled in the rusted runoff drain beneath the catwalk, tethered by a length of barnacled chain; it stirs when fresh blood or spoken vows hit the air.
weaknesses: Do not bleed—wrap cuts, avoid sharp edges
Do not speak vows or promises aloud near the drain
Dry salt thrown into the drain crusts its gills long enough to pass

fail_conditions.name: Forcing the maintenance hatch
fail_conditions.description: The hatch is wired to a crude contact alarm that pings both Harbor Authority maintenance logs and a Tideglass runner who ‘services’ the panel. Forcing it draws attention fast in a place where paperwork and cult timing cooperate.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: A muted chirp clicks once, then the docklight above the catwalk stutters into a steady, accusatory burn. Within minutes, footsteps and radio murmurs begin to braid through the fog as someone comes to see what got logged.
escape_conditions: Kill the docklight breaker and leave before the sweep reaches the lane
Leave a plausible maintenance tag and tool marks consistent with Harbor work
Move onto the adjacent container roofs where fog hides silhouettes

fail_conditions.name: Saying the sea-debt aloud
fail_conditions.description: Certain words act like a hook here; the harbor ‘listens’ through drains and chain. Speaking the debt draws the Salt-Woken and also flags Tideglass listeners trained to catch the phrasing.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The drain below answers with a wet scrape, chain tightening like a throat clearing. Fog thickens in a tight pocket around the speaker, and something cold and patient begins to climb toward the sound while a watcher quietly marks the time.
escape_conditions: Go silent and back away from the drain; do not run on the catwalk
Throw dry salt or powdered lime into the drain to stall the creature
Break line-of-sight by dropping to the lower service lane and moving with the compressor noise

secrets.description: Behind the ‘COLD METAL / FOR A’ stencil, a thin plate is magnet-pinned over a Tideglass cache: a folded tide-table annotated with bloodline initials and dates, including a mark that matches Rafe’s family cadence—next window circled in greasy pencil.

The catwalk’s newest bolt heads are wrong—freshly replaced with Harbor Authority inventory marks. Under one, a microfilm sleeve is taped inside the railing: doctored incident photos showing a ‘slip’ that is clearly a bound offering, with the Union foreman cropped out.

fail_conditions.name: Lean too far over the stuttering light pool
fail_conditions.description: The docklight pattern is timed to induce missteps—depth cues warp in the fog, and the boards nearest the edge are softened by brine-resin. The water here is hungry and quiet, and something below is trained to pull when weight shifts wrong.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: Your footing skates on the slick resin and the edge gives just enough to betray you. Cold black water closes over your head with a soft, practiced tug, and the fog swallows your shout before it becomes sound.
escape_conditions: Hook an elbow on a cleat or chain before going fully under
Cut yourself free of any snagging line with a blade
Get a hand on the ladder-rung bolted under the pier (requires knowing it’s there or frantic searching)

fail_conditions.name: Say the sea-god’s title aloud on the pier
fail_conditions.description: Sound carries oddly in the fog here; certain words are treated like a bell. The Fellowship has conditioned the pier with offerings and brine-resin so that speaking the title draws attention—human and otherwise.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The air tightens as if it’s listening, and the buoy bell slips half a beat out of time. A watcher shifts closer in the fog, and the water under the pilings answers with a soft knock—like a knuckle on a coffin lid.
escape_conditions: Immediately change location to break the sound-map (move into container alleys)
Cover the follow-up conversation with loud mechanical noise (start a generator, slam a container door repeatedly)
Use a mundane explanation loudly ('heritage plaque title') to muddy intent

secrets.description: A Harbor Authority incident ledger page is wedged behind a loose memorial plaque: it lists three 'accidental' drownings with identical tide timestamps and a payout code tied to an old family trust. The Calder name is not written, but the victims’ middle names match known Calder maternal lines.

Under the pier, a rusted ladder rung has been newly replaced with marine-grade steel stamped with the Tideglass crest, forming a concealed handhold route to a small ritual shelf: waxy brine candles, a fishhook charm, and a strip of oilskin with a bloodline chart sketched in dock-ink.

Ward The Fog Line.location_description: Ward The Fog Line is a narrow service strip between stacked containers and the outer pilings where the fog clings like wet cloth. Under the salt-glazed grates, old storm drains empty straight into the black water; someone has been rinsing more than fish blood down here. The docklights stutter in a repeating pattern that matches tide charts, not wiring faults—like the place itself is keeping ritual time.

watchers.name: Inspector Lysa Marr (Harbor Authority Night Compliance)
watchers.description: She watches from a parked incident van with blackout curtains, tracking who enters the Fog Line and which names get spoken on the radio. She’s looking for anyone asking about ‘accidents’ tied to the Calder line and for signs a drowning is about to be reclassified.

watchers.name: Brother Senn of Tideglass (Buoy-Keeper)
watchers.description: He drifts through the fog in oilskins, pretending to check a buoy bell line while listening for confessions and bargaining language. He’s looking for bloodline talk, debt talk, and anyone trying to interrupt tonight’s timing.

hidden_guards.name: Brinehand ‘hook-walkers’ on catwalks (2 longshore enforcers)
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: On the second-level container catwalk above the Fog Line, behind a dangling curtain of netting and tarps; they have sightlines to the service lane and the nearest ladder down to the water.
weaknesses: Stay off the open lane; move under the catwalk shadows and keep to the container seams
Offer a plausible work order or Harbor Authority clearance number (realistic paperwork buys time)
Loud mechanical noise (dropping a pallet chain, slamming a container latch) masks footsteps and radio chatter

hidden_guards.name: Saltwrit Barnacle-Thing (anchored ward-creature)
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Clinging to the underside of the lowest pier beam where the storm drain outflow meets the tide; it’s invisible until water is disturbed or a light hits the wet growth at the right angle.
weaknesses: Do not break the waterline; keep boots dry and avoid splashing near the outflow
Bright steady light held on it forces it to retreat into the growth for a few seconds
Copper or iron filings thrown into the outflow foul its grip and make it sluggish

fail_conditions.name: Pushing into the storm-drain outflow to search for evidence
fail_conditions.description: The outflow is part of a Tideglass ward that ‘pulls’ anything living toward the water when the tide turns. In the Fog Line, the current is deceptively strong and the slick grates make footing unreliable.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The water grabs like a hand around the ankle, yanking hard enough to slam knees into the grate. Salt floods the mouth and nose with a cold, metallic bite, and something rough—barnacle or bone—scrapes skin as it drags. The fog swallows any shout, turning it into a distant echo that sounds like a buoy bell.
escape_conditions: Cut free anything snagged and crawl to the ladder rung bolted into the pier beam
Use a rope, chain, or hook to anchor to a piling before approaching the outflow
Shine a steady light into the water to force the ward-creature to loosen for a moment

fail_conditions.name: Confronting the wrong authority figure about ‘ritual drownings’ in public
fail_conditions.description: The Harbor Authority has a practiced system for turning questions into paperwork, then turning paperwork into leverage. In this ward, radios are always on and names travel faster than footsteps.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: A polite conversation becomes an ‘incident interview’ with your words logged and time-stamped. Within minutes, dock access gates in the area start failing closed, and a patrol car rolls through slow with lights off. By the next tide cycle, someone you trust gets a quiet visit and a warning wrapped in official language.
escape_conditions: Keep it framed as a safety concern or insurance discrepancy, not a cult or ritual
Use intermediaries (Union foreman, contractor channel) instead of direct accusations
Leave the ward before your name is fully confirmed and cross to a different dock sector

secrets.description: Behind a rusted ‘NO ACCESS’ placard on the third container from the waterline is a Tideglass tide-slate: a chalky glass tablet etched with names and dates. One name is partially scraped away—‘Cal…’—and the next scheduled mark aligns with the buoy bell’s off-beat timing.

Under the slick grate near the storm-drain, a small bundle is wired to the frame: a waterlogged wallet, a Harbor Authority incident tag, and a strip of copper stamped with the Calder family knot-mark. The tag number matches a ‘missing during storm’ case that was never officially opened.

Cold Metal For A.location_description: Cold Metal For A is a dead-end service catwalk bolted to the back of a refrigerated container stack labeled in flaking stencil: COLD METAL / FOR A. The catwalk sweats brine; every step rings like a confession. A maintenance hatch here hides a Tideglass tide-table cache and a salt-caked drain that feeds straight into the harbor, making the air taste faintly coppery when the water pulls.

watchers.name: Inspector Lysa Vane (Harbor Authority night audit)
watchers.description: She watches from a parked incident van with the lights off, using a long-lens camera through fog-streaked glass. She’s looking for anyone photographing containers, checking seals, or asking after the Calder name—anything that could turn an ‘accident’ into a case.

watchers.name: Brother Silt (Tideglass dockside volunteer)
watchers.description: He drifts the perimeter as a ‘buoy-maintenance volunteer,’ counting footsteps by sound and timing breaths between the docklight buzz. He’s listening for names, debts, and any mention of tide tables or bloodlines, ready to mark the speaker for later.

hidden_guards.name: Brinehand ‘quiet crew’ enforcer behind the reefer stack
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Crouched in the narrow lane between the refrigerated units and the corrugated shutter, masked by compressor noise and fog; he has line-of-sight to the catwalk ladder.
weaknesses: Approach from the waterline side where the compressors drown footfalls
Keep hands visible and talk like a contractor on a job ticket
Bright light to the eyes breaks his aim in the fog

hidden_guards.name: Salt-Woken chainling in the drain mouth
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Coiled in the rusted runoff drain beneath the catwalk, tethered by a length of barnacled chain; it stirs when fresh blood or spoken vows hit the air.
weaknesses: Do not bleed—wrap cuts, avoid sharp edges
Do not speak vows or promises aloud near the drain
Dry salt thrown into the drain crusts its gills long enough to pass

fail_conditions.name: Forcing the maintenance hatch
fail_conditions.description: The hatch is wired to a crude contact alarm that pings both Harbor Authority maintenance logs and a Tideglass runner who ‘services’ the panel. Forcing it draws attention fast in a place where paperwork and cult timing cooperate.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: A muted chirp clicks once, then the docklight above the catwalk stutters into a steady, accusatory burn. Within minutes, footsteps and radio murmurs begin to braid through the fog as someone comes to see what got logged.
escape_conditions: Kill the docklight breaker and leave before the sweep reaches the lane
Leave a plausible maintenance tag and tool marks consistent with Harbor work
Move onto the adjacent container roofs where fog hides silhouettes

fail_conditions.name: Saying the sea-debt aloud
fail_conditions.description: Certain words act like a hook here; the harbor ‘listens’ through drains and chain. Speaking the debt draws the Salt-Woken and also flags Tideglass listeners trained to catch the phrasing.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The drain below answers with a wet scrape, chain tightening like a throat clearing. Fog thickens in a tight pocket around the speaker, and something cold and patient begins to climb toward the sound while a watcher quietly marks the time.
escape_conditions: Go silent and back away from the drain; do not run on the catwalk
Throw dry salt or powdered lime into the drain to stall the creature
Break line-of-sight by dropping to the lower service lane and moving with the compressor noise

secrets.description: Behind the ‘COLD METAL / FOR A’ stencil, a thin plate is magnet-pinned over a Tideglass cache: a folded tide-table annotated with bloodline initials and dates, including a mark that matches Rafe’s family cadence—next window circled in greasy pencil.

The catwalk’s newest bolt heads are wrong—freshly replaced with Harbor Authority inventory marks. Under one, a microfilm sleeve is taped inside the railing: doctored incident photos showing a ‘slip’ that is clearly a bound offering, with the Union foreman cropped out.

His Nose And Use The.location_description: Behind the humor of the name, "His Nose And Use The" is a narrow dockside dead-end: a wind-bent gangway, a corrugated shed with a painted nose logo, and a brine-stiffened net loft above. The air here tastes sharper than the rest of the harbor, like salt laid directly on the tongue, and the fog clings to faces—especially around the nostrils—as if testing who belongs. A Tideglass memorial buoy hangs from a beam like a charm, but the rope is new and the knot-work is old, ritual-precise.

watchers.name: Inspector Marn Vell (Harbor Authority night auditor)
watchers.description: He watches from a parked incident-response skiff with its cabin lights off, logging who comes and goes by silhouette and footfall rhythm. He's looking for Calder involvement, any mention of "missing" cargo, and whether tonight's schedule lines up with a Tideglass tide window.

watchers.name: Sister Lorn (Tideglass Fellowship shore-warden)
watchers.description: She watches through the fog from the net loft, pretending to mend rope while counting breaths and listening for names. She's looking for anyone asking about debts, bloodlines, or the memorial buoy—especially if they speak like they already know the answer.

hidden_guards.name: Brinehand "dock-saints" (two union enforcers in oilskins)
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Crouched behind stacked crab pots under the gangway, where the fog pools and footsteps sound like they come from the water.
weaknesses: Avoid the gangway choke point; approach from the seaward side along the pilings.
Flash an authentic Brinehand token or name a known foreman to buy a few minutes.
Bright light to the eyes breaks their advantage in fog long enough to slip past.

hidden_guards.name: The Silt-Mouth (a tide-sent thing wearing a drowned man's jawline)
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Below the dock edge directly under the hanging memorial buoy, fingers hooked into the algae-slick piling like a patient climber.
weaknesses: Do not speak your full name near the buoy; it reacts to named claims.
Cold iron (not stainless) laid against the piling forces it to release for a moment.
Keep moving—if it cannot match your pace, it retreats to the waterline.

fail_conditions.name: Touching or cutting the memorial buoy line
fail_conditions.description: The buoy is a Tideglass-tuned anchor for a claim: it doesn't just hang there, it listens. Disturbing the line tightens the sea-god's attention like a noose and makes the dock feel suddenly too narrow to stand on.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The bell gives one off-beat chime that doesn't match the harbor's rhythm, and the fog thickens into a wet wall. A hand like cold kelp hooks an ankle; the dock boards sweat brine and turn slick, pitching the victim toward black water that feels hungry and familiar. Even if no one falls, witnesses nearby suddenly "remember" seeing an accident and start moving to make it true.
escape_conditions: Back away without turning your back to the water and keep your feet wide, low, and steady.
Press cold iron to the piling or buoy shackle to break the pull long enough to retreat.
Speak a false name (not your own) and spit saltwater to misdirect the claim.

fail_conditions.name: Mentioning Calder debt aloud in earshot
fail_conditions.description: Names carry weight here; debts carry hunger. Saying the Calder debt out loud draws both human and inhuman attention—Authority paperwork predators and Tideglass listeners—turning a quiet inquiry into a scheduled drowning.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: A watcher marks the time and repeats the words into a radio or a prayer, and the harbor seems to lean closer. Within minutes, union muscle drifts into position "for safety," while the fog rearranges sightlines so exits feel farther than they are. The next official record will already be writing itself as an accident report with your name in the margins.
escape_conditions: Switch to coded language (cargo numbers, tide times) and stop using family names.
Create a distraction that forces watchers to look elsewhere (flare, dropped crate, staged argument).
Leave the scene before the next buoy-bell interval (roughly three slow chimes).

secrets.description: Under the shed's nose-logo sign is a newer plank hiding an older Tideglass inlay: a spiral of glass chips set into tar, matching the Fellowship's bloodline map marks. A thin smear of coppery residue (fresh) outlines the spiral as if someone traced it with a bleeding thumb.

In the net loft, a ledger wrapped in oilcloth lists "incident cleanups" paid by Harbor Authority to a shell contractor. The dates align with known drownings, and one entry is labeled only "Nose / Use / Calder—deferred," implying Rafe's line is being managed, not hunted at random.

Ward The Vent Screws.location_description: Ward The Vent Screws is a narrow service ward beneath the dockline where ventilation stacks and pressure valves (“vent screws”) hiss brine-heavy air from old storm drains into the container alleys. The concrete sweats salt; rust blooms around bolted plates; and every few minutes the vents exhale a fog that briefly hides footprints and faces. The ward is unofficially controlled through maintenance permits and “safety” inspections—perfect cover for staged accidents and quiet rites.

watchers.name: Inspector Lysa Morcant
watchers.description: She watches from a parked Harbor Authority skiff-van with its hazard lights dimmed, using a thermal monocular and a clipboard that’s mostly blank. She’s looking for familiar Calder features and for anyone approaching the vent manifolds during fog cycles, logging times to later reframe as routine safety checks.

watchers.name: Brother Tern (Tideglass Almoner)
watchers.description: He poses as a charity volunteer tightening memorial ribbons on a nearby buoy-post, but his real attention is on reflections in puddles and the rhythm of the buoy bell. He’s listening for names spoken aloud and watching who touches the vent screws with bare skin, marking them as “salt-ready.”

hidden_guards.name: Brinehand 'Safety Crew' Enforcers (2 dockhands in slickers)
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Behind a corrugated shutter labeled VENT MAINT—AUTHORIZED ONLY, posted in a recessed alcove beside the main manifold where the fog vents strongest.
weaknesses: Approach during a vent exhale when visibility drops; they hesitate to fire blind.
Present a stamped Harbor Authority work order (real or convincing forgery) to make them stand down temporarily.
Create a distraction at the far drain grates; they reflexively check for 'wash-back' before committing.

hidden_guards.name: Salt-Wake Leeching Mist (bound ward-thing)
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Inside the vent stack throats and the low fog layer; it clings to breath and exposed skin near the screw-heads etched with old tide-marks.
weaknesses: Cover mouth and nose with a diesel-soaked rag or proper respirator; it feeds on breath.
Break the fog cycle by closing the upstream valve two turns counterclockwise (requires strength/tools).
Salt it with dry lime or ash to force it to shed and retreat into the vents.

fail_conditions.name: Forcing the vent screw too fast
fail_conditions.description: The vent screws are pressure-locked; cranking them hard can trigger a brine blowback that knocks a person down and floods the ward with choking mist. The ward’s slick concrete and open drain mouths make a fall here feel like being guided.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The screw snaps a quarter-turn free with a wet pop, and the vent exhales like a lung full of seawater. Mist slams into your face; your footing skates out, and the drain grates suddenly sound closer than they should. In the fog, something tugs at your sleeve like a patient hand trying to finish an old story.
escape_conditions: Go prone and crawl toward the wall bolts to regain traction, staying out of the drain’s pull.
Seal the vent with a tarp/jacket and weight it down to reduce blowback.
Back the screw one notch and wait for the pressure to equalize between cycles.

fail_conditions.name: Saying the wrong name in the ward
fail_conditions.description: Words carry strangely here; the vents echo and distort, and certain names act like hooks. Speaking them can alert both human watchers and the bound mist, turning the ward into a listening throat.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The fog stills for a beat, as if it’s paying attention. A buoy bell outside strikes off-time, and footsteps pause where they shouldn’t—someone has heard you without being near. The mist thickens around your mouth, tasting you like it’s deciding whether you’re due.
escape_conditions: Lower your voice and switch to hand signals; stop feeding the echo.
Move out of the vent corridor into open dock air where sound disperses.
Mask your speech with loud ambient noise (kick a loose plate, start a generator, trigger an alarm).

secrets.description: Behind the VENT MAINT shutter, a rusted maintenance ledger is hidden inside a waterproof pipe sleeve. The entries are coded as 'filter swaps' and 'pressure tests,' but the dates align with reported drownings; one column marks 'C' for Calder-adjacent bloodlines and lists a payoff route through Harbor Authority claims.

Under the main manifold, the concrete has been chiseled and re-cemented in a crude circle. Beneath it is a Tideglass charm: a glass bead rosary threaded with copper wire and knotted hair, anchored to a drain bolt; it 'tunes' the fog cycles to coincide with specific names and shifts.

locations: Service corridor access panel (FILES/Compliance back wall)

Ing Boots.location_description: Ing Boots is a narrow dockside workwear shop wedged between a bait freezer and a shuttered chandlery. The public floor smells of oiled leather and mildew, but the back wall is newer than it should be, hiding a bricked-over doorway to an old tide tunnel. Salt has crusted in a crescent pattern under the counter as if the floor has been briefly underwater more than once.

watchers.name: Mara Quell (counter clerk)
watchers.description: Acts bored and helpful while clocking hands, shoes, and pockets; she watches for anyone asking about missing dockworkers, unusual boot sizes, or purchases that suggest wading or anchoring. She quietly notes names and the direction they leave, then makes a "stock call" that is really a report.

watchers.name: Inspector Halden Rusk (outside, in an unmarked sedan)
watchers.description: Watches the storefront through fogged glass and a cracked mirror tucked in his visor; he’s looking for Rafe or anyone snooping around Ing Boots after-hours. He tracks who enters, how long they stay, and whether they leave with a box big enough to hide ledgers or wet gear.

hidden_guards.name: Backroom "stockman" with a union hook-knife
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Behind the false back wall in the rear stockroom, sitting on a milk crate beside a pallet of rubber waders; he can step through a narrow service gap when the panel is unlatched.
weaknesses: Keep to the public floor and avoid touching the back wall seams
Offer a plausible work order or delivery manifest to stall him
Bright light to the eyes buys seconds; he hates being seen

hidden_guards.name: Salt-slick ward on the threshold
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: A crescent of salt embedded under the counter and along the baseboard leading to the stockroom; it clings to boots and tracks anyone who crosses toward the hidden doorway.
weaknesses: Step over the crescent without touching it (dry soles, no drag)
Scatter ash or iron filings to disrupt the pattern
Rinse the soles with fresh water before moving deeper to reduce the mark

fail_conditions.name: Pushing into the stockroom without a cover story
fail_conditions.description: Ing Boots is a choke point used for quiet handoffs; anyone moving like they’re hunting for something gets treated like a thief or a witness. The shop’s back area is rigged for quick containment and fast calls to muscle.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The clerk’s tone turns flat as she reaches under the counter, and the bell over the door is quietly jammed so it won’t ring again. A moment later, a heavy step sounds from behind the wall and a blade flashes low, aimed at tendons, not hearts. You’re forced into a tight, ugly choice: back off publicly or get dragged into the back where no one hears you.
escape_conditions: Retreat to the public floor and buy something to reset suspicion
Name a believable dock job and a supervisor the clerk might recognize
Create a distraction (spill, alarm, power flicker) and leave before the backroom opens

fail_conditions.name: Breaking or smearing the salt crescent
fail_conditions.description: The ward isn’t just a warning; it’s a claim-marker. Disturbing it calls attention in a way that travels through damp wood and old masonry like a pulse, inviting both human and not-quite-human response.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The air goes cold and wet, as if the room inhales from the harbor. Salt blooms on your tongue and your boots feel heavier, tugged toward the floor like a tide turning. Outside, the buoy bell seems to strike closer, and someone—somewhere—knows your weight, your pace, and your direction.
escape_conditions: Wash hands and soles with fresh water and soap to dull the mark
Leave the building immediately and change footwear before going to the docks
Ground yourself with iron (coin, nail, hook) held in the fist until the nausea passes

secrets.description: A ledger page is stitched into the lining of a display boot: names, dates, and tide times coded as shoe sizes, with a recurring mark beside "Calder" that matches Tideglass memorial plaques.

Behind a rack of oilskins, a newer plank floor hides an iron ring set into old stone; it lifts to a sealed hatch that smells like brine and pennies, leading toward a forgotten tide tunnel under the block.

Ward The Union Voices With.location_description: Ward The Union Voices With is a narrow dockside meeting hall wedged between container stacks and a shuttered net-mender’s shop. The walls sweat salt; old union posters hide newer Tideglass sigils scratched into the plaster. A low, off-beat buoy bell seems louder here, as if the building is tuned to it, and the floorboards nearest the back door stay damp no matter the weather—brine seeping up like a slow, patient breath.

watchers.name: Marta 'Ledger' Venn
watchers.description: A union clerk with ink-stained fingers who never looks up directly; she listens through the rhythm of boots on boards and the way voices break on certain names. She’s tracking who asks about drownings, who mentions the Calders, and who seems to be counting exits.

watchers.name: Inspector Halden Rusk
watchers.description: Harbor Authority plainclothes posted outside in the fog, pretending to smoke near a power junction box. He watches reflections in puddles and window-glass to read who enters and leaves, and he’s looking for anyone prying into 'accidents' tied to the ward’s back-room ledger.

hidden_guards.name: Brinehand 'Hookman' in the rafters
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: In the dark crossbeams above the back-room door, lying on planks behind a hanging tarp of oilskins, with a gaff hook and a short-barrel flare gun.
weaknesses: Keep hands visible and stay in the main room; don’t approach the back-room door without being invited
Bright light upward (phone/flashlight) forces him to blink and shift, giving away position
Offer union business (work, payment, a name) to de-escalate before he commits

hidden_guards.name: Salt-licked Ward-Sentinel
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: In the water beneath the pier-side window, anchored to a barnacled chain; it rises only as a slick, human-shaped ripple when the ward is threatened.
weaknesses: Do not shed blood in the ward; even a cut lip can call it closer
Dry salt and iron filings scattered at the sill disrupt its grip long enough to retreat
Move away from open water and keep to higher ground; it cannot climb dry boards far from the tide

fail_conditions.name: Pressing the Calder sea-debt in public
fail_conditions.description: The ward is a listening post; saying the wrong thing turns a meeting into a hunt. The Union protects its bargains, and the Authority prefers 'accidents' to stay tidy.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: Conversations stop one by one until the room is all silence and eyes. Someone slips out to fetch muscle, and within minutes exits are quietly watched and your name is paired with a time and a tide. Any further push risks being steered toward the water under the guise of 'walking you out.'
escape_conditions: Back off and reframe as a routine investigation-for-hire without mentioning bloodlines or gods
Offer a trade: a recovered cargo lead or protection job in exchange for information
Leave immediately through the main door before the back-room runner returns

fail_conditions.name: Forcing entry into the back room
fail_conditions.description: The back room holds the ward’s real accounts—names, tides, and payments. The Union treats it like a throat: touch it wrong and the whole body bites.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The Hookman drops without warning, pinning you with the gaff while the flare gun turns the room into harsh, accusing daylight. In the confusion, someone calls Harbor Authority 'for safety,' and the official response arrives ready to classify whatever happens next as an unfortunate accident. If you’re dragged outside, the tide under the pier is already waiting.
escape_conditions: Freeze and negotiate immediately; offer to return any taken item and pay a 'fine'
Create a distraction in the main room (fire alarm, breaker switch) to break line of sight and slip out
Get to a crowded, well-lit public stretch of dock where 'accidents' are harder to stage

secrets.description: Behind a peeling union poster is a Tideglass chalk-mark: a tide chart encoded as a hymn stanza, listing three upcoming drownings by date and moon phase. One name is smudged out, but the initial 'C' remains, pressed hard enough to dent the plaster.

Under the warped floorboard near the back-room threshold is a small, tar-wrapped packet: a Harbor Authority incident tag stamped 'RECOVERED—UNCLAIMED' and a rusted key that smells of kelp. The tag number matches a case that was officially closed as a storm accident—the night Rafe’s father vanished.

Docklight With My Palms.location_description: Docklight With My Palms is a narrow service pier wedged between stacked containers and a shuttered bait warehouse. The docklights here are intentionally miswired to stutter in a repeating pattern that masks movement on the water; the slick on the pilings isn’t just algae but a thin, waxy brine-resin used in Tideglass rites. Under the constant diesel stink, there’s a faint copper-salt note that never fully dissipates—old blood washed thin and made to look like rust runoff.

watchers.name: Deputy Inspector Mara Venn
watchers.description: She watches from a Harbor Authority skiff idling in the fog line, logging who enters the pier and how long they stay. She’s looking for Calder-linked faces and anyone asking about recent 'accidents' before the paperwork can be sealed.

watchers.name: Brother Sable (Tideglass Warden)
watchers.description: He listens more than he looks—stationed as a 'volunteer' checking memorial plaques, he uses a conch-shell earpiece to catch names carried by the wind. He’s hunting for anyone who speaks the sea-god’s titles aloud or mentions breaking the debt, then marks them for later.

hidden_guards.name: Brinehand 'Night Hands' in oilskins
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Two union enforcers tucked behind the corrugated bait-warehouse shutters, watching through a slit where rust has been scraped clean; they have a clear angle down the pier to the stuttering docklight pool.
weaknesses: Approach from the waterline under the pier where their sightline breaks
Use Harbor Authority credentials or inspection language to make them hesitate
Bright, steady light (flare/flash) ruins their night-adapted advantage for a moment

hidden_guards.name: Salt-Slick Mireling
hidden_guards.location_within_scene: Clinging under the third piling from the end, just below the tide mark; it surfaces only when it tastes fresh blood or hears the old sea-name spoken.
weaknesses: Do not bleed—bandage cuts, avoid splinters and hooks
Freshwater (bottle or hose) makes it recoil and lose grip
Keep moving on dry boards; it is slow to climb above the tide line

fail_conditions.name: Lean too far over the stuttering light pool
fail_conditions.description: The docklight pattern is timed to induce missteps—depth cues warp in the fog, and the boards nearest the edge are softened by brine-resin. The water here is hungry and quiet, and something below is trained to pull when weight shifts wrong.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: Your footing skates on the slick resin and the edge gives just enough to betray you. Cold black water closes over your head with a soft, practiced tug, and the fog swallows your shout before it becomes sound.
escape_conditions: Hook an elbow on a cleat or chain before going fully under
Cut yourself free of any snagging line with a blade
Get a hand on the ladder-rung bolted under the pier (requires knowing it’s there or frantic searching)

fail_conditions.name: Say the sea-god’s title aloud on the pier
fail_conditions.description: Sound carries oddly in the fog here; certain words are treated like a bell. The Fellowship has conditioned the pier with offerings and brine-resin so that speaking the title draws attention—human and otherwise.
fail_conditions.consequence_narrative: The air tightens as if it’s listening, and the buoy bell slips half a beat out of time. A watcher shifts closer in the fog, and the water under the pilings answers with a soft knock—like a knuckle on a coffin lid.
escape_conditions: Immediately change location to break the sound-map (move into container alleys)
Cover the follow-up conversation with loud mechanical noise (start a generator, slam a container door repeatedly)
Use a mundane explanation loudly ('heritage plaque title') to muddy intent

secrets.description: A Harbor Authority incident ledger page is wedged behind a loose memorial plaque: it lists three 'accidental' drownings with identical tide timestamps and a payout code tied to an old family trust. The Calder name is not written, but the victims’ middle names match known Calder maternal lines.

Under the pier, a rusted ladder rung has been newly replaced with marine-grade steel stamped with the Tideglass crest, forming a concealed handhold route to a small ritual shelf: waxy brine candles, a fishhook charm, and a strip of oilskin with a bloodline chart sketched in dock-ink.

Ward The Fog Line.location_description: Ward The Fog Line is a narrow service strip between stacked containers and the outer pilings where the fog clings like wet cloth. Under the salt-glazed grates, old storm drains empty straight into the black water; someone has been rinsing more than fish blood down here. The docklights stutter in a repeating pattern that matches tide charts, not wiring faults—like the place itself is keeping ritual time.

watchers.name: Inspector Lysa Marr (Harbor Authority Night Compliance)
watchers.description: She watches from a parked incident van with blackout curtains, tracking who enters the Fog Line and which names get spoken on the radio. She’s looking for anyone asking about ‘accidents’ tied to the Calder line and for signs a drowning is about to be reclassified.

watchers.name: Brother Senn of Tideglass (Buoy-Keeper)
watchers.description: He drifts through the fog in oilskins, pretending to check a buoy bell line while listening for confessions and bargaining language. He’s looking for bloodline talk, debt talk, and anyone trying to interrupt tonight’s timing.
